title: Letters to Sports: Readers debate whether the Dodgers are ruining baseball
description: Readers of the Los Angeles Times give their thoughts on the Dodgers signing Kyle Tucker, the Rams, the LeBron James-Jeanie Buss rift and college football.
fullText:
The fury over the Dodgers signing Kyle Tucker makes me wonder who's shouting the loudest?

Could it be desperate, unfortunate fans whose beloved teams are owned by inheritors, nepo families, or private equity bros who celebrate their glamorous assets?

So how about a new metric in the sports page to accompany the ranking of teams and players: ownership. Not simply by wealth, but wisdom, brains and commitment. And for fun let's call it the McCourt-Moreno Index.

It's time we hold the Marge Schotts of pro sports accountable for the franchises they mismanage.

There are some alarming implications to Bill Plaschke's "If it blows up baseball, so be it." Perhaps he means that MLB should be reduced to a burning garbage heap with three teams atop ‚Äî Yankees, Cubs and Dodgers ‚Äî because they were the only ones who went into the TV business and peddled their services for billions in the three largest TV markets.

Maybe he yearns to transform MLB into the NHL of my childhood, with six teams. That was OK if you lived in a shallow arc extending between New York and Chicago ‚Äî not so good for everyone else.

"So be it," as Plaschke would say, but I can guarantee I won't be the only one who isn't watching anymore.

Naturally Dodger fans are all excited about the signing of the $60-million-a-year All-Star right fielder, Kyle Tucker. But we're not going to be happy when Dodger Stadium becomes the first MLB ballpark with a two-drink minimum.

As everyone seems to be raving about the Dodgers' acquisition of Kyle Tucker, I note the following: There is another player who was recently signed by the Yankees for less money and less signing bonus than Tucker who had higher numbers last year in average, home runs and WAR. He also plays more positions. Hadn‚Äôt the Dodgers heard of Cody Bellinger? Bellinger as a Yankee will never feel right to me.

Ask a Major League Baseball owner like Arte Moreno, who sells out his ballpark whenever the Dodgers come to Anaheim, and sees Angel broadcast ratings surge whenever his team plays the Dodgers, if he thinks the Dodgers are ruining the game.

The Rams won the battle of which team gets to lose to Seattle.

The NFL needs to clarify exactly what does and doesn‚Äôt constitute pass interference. There is no consistency as to how it's called with each official seeming to have their own definition of what constitutes pass interference. It has gotten to the point where it‚Äôs worse than major league umpires and their own definition of the strike zone. NFL, you need to clean this up because these are major calls that are ruining games.

Bill Plaschke finally wrote a column about the Lakers with which I agree. LeBron James is the past, Austin Reaves is the future, and $50 million will help the Lakers rebuild. Yes, it's really as simple as that.

With the Lakers defense costing them multiple games, reminiscent of the coach Mike (no D)'Antoni days, the only real interesting Laker news last week were the alleged Jeanie Buss comments about the King. They sounded like they were lines taken from a scene in "The Godfather" .... "What have I done to make you treat me so disrespectfully." My opinion is that it "was not personal and strictly business."

When asked after each game how he'd celebrate another victory, Indiana's Curt Cignetti would say, "With a beer." After guiding his team to an undefeated season, and then winning the national championship, I doubt the Hoosiers' coach will ever have to buy another beer again.

Lincoln Riley is officially on the clock. In two years Curt Cignetti took a woebegone college team, with nary a five-star player, to an undefeated national championship. Cignetti has proven that, even in the NIL era, coaching matters. Tick, tick, tick, tick, tick ‚Ä¶

Curt Cignetti and Indiana football playing in and winning the national championship was a modern-day version of the movie "Hoosiers" and would have made coach Norman Dale (actor Gene Hackman) proud. Now the question is, can new UCLA football coach Bob Chesney and his 40-plus transfers be the second coming of Indiana? Only time will tell.

Kings president Luc Robitaille appears to be happy with the Kings' status quo that appears to be getting one point every game in an overtime or shootout loss. Should we start referring to him as Luc RobitailleandthenloseinOT?

The Los Angeles Times welcomes expressions of all views. Letters should be brief and become the property of The Times. They may be edited and republished in any format. Each must include a valid mailing address and telephone number. Pseudonyms will not be used.

Get the best, most interesting and strangest stories of the day from the L.A. sports scene and beyond from our newsletter The Sports Report.

This story originally appeared in Los Angeles Times.

title: Brenna Huckaby, Paralympic snowboarder, relies on the power of sports
description: Brenna Huckaby lost her leg to cancer when she was 14 years old. Then she discovered snowboarding, and it opened her entire world.
fullText:
If we could ski down a mountain, then when we got home, we were able to conquer everyday life things.

At the time, Brenna Huckaby didn‚Äôt fully realize what the idea behind that rehabilitative trip to Utah would mean to her.

She had been diagnosed with osteosarcoma, a form of bone cancer, and lost her right leg at 14. To that point, conquering everyday things had meant wearing her prosthetic leg consistently.

But the trip, sponsored by her hospital, which sent Huckaby and kids who lost mobility from osteosarcoma to the slopes, opened up her world.

"I fell in love with it immediately," she tells USA TODAY Sports. "It was the first sport that I had found just not only (an) incredible challenge, but also this fear and this knowing that I could do it, and I wanted to do it."

Huckaby, now 30, became an American Paralympic snowboarder who will once again be competing at the Olympics, this time at Milano Cortina. She won gold and bronze at Beijing in 2022.

Have you ever taken the time to think about what sports, especially your favorite sport, means to you?

We caught up with Huckaby, who would also become the first Paralympian to appear in the Swimsuit Issue of Sports Illustrated and is now a sports mom, about how sports can give us the confidence to take on life‚Äôs biggest challenges.

If we set a goal, and we push ourselves, we can reap their benefits at no matter what level we achieve.

YOUTH SPORTS SURVIVAL GUIDE:¬†Pre-order Coach Steve's upcoming book for young athletes and their parents

Huckaby spoke to USA TODAY Sports on behalf of Hershey‚Äôs for the ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs Your Happy Place‚Äù campaign. Athletes partnered with the chocolate and candy company to showcase how happiness is not only found in winning, but sweet, everyday moments.

Those moments, she says, "don‚Äôt have to be big and explosive." The small ones can matter the most.

"I feel like that's been my main focus the last eight years," she says. "How can I enjoy the process, enjoy the journey, not just the destination? And I feel like that's way easier said than done. I've learned that taking time to pause, to slow down, to be in the moment, that's how I have found happiness, presence, gratitude, all the things that make me feel good. It‚Äôs been in those tiny moments throughout the day."

As young athletes (and parents), if we take the time to reflect on what we‚Äôre doing as we race to our different sports events, we can improve our awareness. Huckaby‚Äôs sport, she says, is mostly mental, and that part of her game helps her push through the excruciatingly physical parts.

"I feel like I don't make progress and grow unless I am mentally present and in a good headspace to learn," she says. ¬†"I would say the sooner that you can take moments to reflect on ‚Äì whether it's your training in the gym or a practice that you had ‚Äì what was hard, what was good, what do you want to improve on, and what did it teach you about yourself? When you can start practicing that, it makes the things that you've learned so much easier.

"Then you're able to see those moments of growth and (be) like, 'Wow, like I'm so glad that I learned that. And I'm so glad I pushed through that because I've got this thing that I'm dealing with at home and I know that I can take the mindsets from sport and apply it here.'"

Reflection has helped Huckaby realize she performs her best when she‚Äôs calm. She works with a sports psychologist to help her channel her strength to high stakes situations.

Do you remember the instance where you either discovered your favorite sport or realized it was the one you love most?

Huckaby, who has two older brothers (Jordan and Jeremy), loved to jump around as a little girl. Jeremy, her middle brother, and her parents were really into martial arts, which she tried. Her instructor pulled her parents (Jeff and Kristie) aside and told them, "You need to put her in gymnastics."

"What I loved the most was learning how to do flips in the gym and that's what my martial arts teachers would just teach me because that was all I could stay focused for," she says. "So my parents listened and also they were tired of me doing cartwheels in the house and stuff, and they thought it was a way to save their TV."

Huckaby's cancer, which led to the amputation, ended her gymnastics career. But, Huckaby says, she thought about how she loved moving her body and chasing adrenaline.

"When snowboarding came to me, 'I was like, this is it,'" Huckaby says.

She moved to Utah, about a year after the hospital-led trip with her mom, who worked as a nurse there. The rest of the family stayed at their home in Louisiana, and Kristie moved back home when her daughter graduated high school.

"It gave me opportunity to just heal from cancer through snowboarding," Huckaby says. "Sports (is) such a great way to understand life in the way that it challenges you and the way that you intimately get to know who you are.

"You gain so much confidence in your body and what your body's capable of. So during cancer, I never really questioned that I could handle it. I put myself in extreme situations through gymnastics training that I knew that I could handle what was to come.

"I think now as I've been doing this at a professional level for so long, I've learned, 'How do I put that more into my everyday life so that I'm not just an athlete?'"

Huckaby says she doesn‚Äôt so much balance her life, but embraces what‚Äôs important to her through every season.

When she‚Äôs home, she trains vigorously but finds family time every day with her husband, Tristan Klegg, and young school-aged daughters, Lilah and Sloan. Klegg, a former snowboard cross athlete, realizes he sometimes needs to be at home with the girls at times over being with his wife. But they interact daily.

"He takes care of our kids while I'm away and when I'm training and (is) such a big support, making sure that we win, right?" she says. "It's a team effort for sure.

"I'm in the gym in the offseason three to five days a week," she says, "and I say three to five because we're human. It's life, you know? So the ideal, the perfect, is five. The reality is usually three, and during that period, you're going really hard. And so those off days are really important. And then between snowboard season and gym season, we have two weeks off. We are encouraged to have fun and move our body in ways that feel good, but it doesn't have to be intense. It's just, 'Take time off.'

‚ÄúAnd then I usually give myself a fall break. I know that it's good for my mental health. So usually as Halloween starts rolling around, I'm less intense and then I crank back up (in) November, and then most of December and then (the) holidays, I give myself permission to just chill. Because I know it's about to get serious after Christmas.

"It's (about) finding a rhythm, but I absolutely rest."

Lilah and Sloan, Huckaby‚Äôs daughters, like skateboarding, wakeboarding, wake surfing and other action sports near their home in Montana.

Lilah, her older daughter, has tried gymnastics and does aerial silks, which Huckaby describes as art-based body movements.

"We're active," she says. "That's where we're trying to shine. I don't ever want them to think anything has just been given to me and easy. Of course, there are moments that it looks easy and it's because of all the decades of work that I've put in on my body and then my mind. And so things look like they come together naturally, but, I love the phrase, 'An overnight success was not built overnight.' It was built, you know, a decade before, just quietly working.

"Like yesterday, I did not want to go to the gym. It was my third day of two-a-days and I was just like, 'I don't want to go.' And they saw that, and I got up and I went."

But Huckaby also never wants her daughters to think that she‚Äôs fearless. She has been scared many times, whether it's during training, free riding or competing.

‚ÄúBut I'm brave, and I do it anyway, and I do it scared, and I trust my training, and I trust myself, and I hope that they learn to do that for themselves," she says.

Huckaby was horrified, she says, when Sports Illustrated approached her to pose for its 2018 swimsuit edition. She thought she wasn‚Äôt confident enough to put herself out in the world in that way.

"Then I just thought about my 14-year-old self who had just lost her leg and was bald at the time and just felt unbeautiful and unworthy, and I remembered that she deserved to be represented in a way that she wanted to, and to be seen as someone who could be beautiful and could be lovable. And so I wanted to give that to her, and I'm so proud of myself for doing that."

In a similar way, we sometimes have to put ourselves, or our kids, out there for our first big competition. It‚Äôs a risk, for sure, but then that rush of adrenaline can come, the one you only get from sports.

"Bet on yourself," Huckaby says, "because you're worth investing in. If you want it, go for it. If you feel like you have what it takes and you love what you're doing, go out there and give yourself the time to do it and the opportunity to do it because that's what matters more than when you got into your sport. It‚Äôs never too late."

We don‚Äôt need to have it all figured out. We might just need more perspective on what we‚Äôre doing, and what we‚Äôre spending.

Borelli, aka Coach Steve,¬†has been an¬†editor and writer with USA TODAY since 1999. He spent 10 years coaching his two sons‚Äô baseball and basketball teams. He and his wife, Colleen, are now sports parents for two high schoolers. His Coach Steve column is posted weekly.¬†For his past columns, click here.

Got a question for Coach Steve you want answered in a column? Email him at¬†sborelli@usatoday.com

This article originally appeared on USA TODAY: How Brenna Huckaby, Paralympic snowboarder, uses power of sports

fullText:
PEORIA, Ill. (WMBD/WYZZ) ‚Äî The Big 12 Conference races stayed tight in both boys and girls basketball on Friday.

League-leading Peoria High beat visiting Notre Dame, 66-39, to improve to 7-0 in the conference. Normal Community beat Manual, 56-50, to move to 5-1 and drop the Rams to 5-2 in the Big 12.

Two teams remain unbeaten in the girls conference race. Notre Dame beat Peoria High and Richwoods beat Danville so both the Irish and Knights improves to 6-0 in the league.

Normal Community‚Äôs win at Manual pushes the Iron to 6-1 in the league.

Other girls basketball winners included Dunlap and Canton. Other boys winners included Metamora, East Peoria, Bloomington, Pontiac, Farmington, Leroy and Tremont.

Tremont‚Äôs Josh Papenhause hit a short shot in the final seconds as the Turks rallied to beat El Paso-Gridley, 71-69, in the semifinals of the McLean County/Heart of Illinois Conference Tournament. The Turks advance to Saturday‚Äôs title game and will face top-seeded LeRoy, which edged Lexington 60-57, in the other semifinal.

fullText:
PEORIA, Ill. (WMBD/WYZZ) ‚Äî Metamora outscored visiting Morton 20-9 in the fourth quarter and rallied to beat the top-ranked Potters, 46-37, in Mid-Illini Conference girls basketball on Thursday.

Sophomore Leah Koster scored 24 points to lead the Redbirds (18-7, 6-3). Metamora trailed Morton 28-26 after three quarters then scored 13 of its 20 fourth-quarter points from the free throw line.

Morton (18-4, 8-1), which moved into the top spot in the class 3A state poll last week after beating then-No. 1 Washington, got 17 points from Abby VanMeenen and 15 from Paige Selke.

Addy Wooden scored 10 and Baylie Nena added nine points for the Redbirds. Morton hosts third-ranked Galesburg on Saturday.

Other girls basketball winners Thursday included Canton, Central Catholic, Tri-Valley and Eureka. Tri-Valley will play Eureka in Saturday‚Äôs title game of the McLean County/Heart of Illinois Conference Tournament after winning semifinal games Thursday.

Boys basketball winners included Morton, Dee-Mack, Tri-Valley and North Fulton.

title: ESPN Deportes' play-by-play of Fernando Mendoza‚Äôs touchdown might be the best sports call of the year
description: One must-watch highlight from the CFP title game.
fullText:
ESPN Deportes' play-by-play of Fernando Mendoza‚Äôs touchdown might be the best sports call of the year originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

Indiana quarterback Fernando Mendoza put together one of the most decorated seasons in modern college football history.

The Heisman Trophy winner led the Hoosiers to a perfect 16-0 record and the program‚Äôs first national championship, marking the first 16-win season in the sport in 132 years.

What nearly got lost in the aftermath of one of college football‚Äôs most memorable seasons was perhaps the call of the year.

Mendoza delivered one of the defining moments of the College Football Playoff title game in Miami Gardens. Facing fourth and 5 in the fourth quarter, he kept the ball on a quarterback draw, slipped past multiple defenders and dove into the end zone for a 12-yard touchdown that pushed Indiana‚Äôs lead to two scores.

This was ESPN's Spanish call as Fernando Mendoza, who is Cuban-American, dove for a touchdown in the national championship game üá®üá∫pic.twitter.com/2rexeBX37F

‚Äî Front Office Sports (@FOS) January 22, 2026

As Miami threatened late, the moment was brought to life on ESPN Deportes, with announcers Eduardo Varela and Pablo Viruega delivering an electric Spanish-language call that quickly circulated across social media.

Their passion captured the stakes and significance of the play as Mendoza etched his name into college football history.

More:¬†Curt Cignetti slams Big 12 refs over Miami's 'dirty' play in title game

Mendoza‚Äôs rise has been rapid since transferring from California before the 2025 season. Under coach Curt Cignetti, he threw for 3,535 yards and an Indiana record 41 touchdowns while completing 72 percent of his passes.

More:¬†Michael Irvin faces backlash after CFP title game

Mendoza is widely projected as the top pick in the 2026 NFL Draft, with the Las Vegas Raiders often mentioned as a potential destination.

title: US sports say parity is essential for success. Premier League proves that untrue
description: There are no salary caps, no aprons, and no luxury taxes, yet the world‚Äôs most-watched soccer league is only getting more balanced
fullText:
There are no salary caps and no luxury taxes, yet the world‚Äôs most-watched soccer league is only getting more balanced

David Stern used to tell a joke. In his early years as NBA commissioner, he liked to say, his job was essentially to travel back and forth between Boston and Los Angeles to hand out the championship trophy. In the first five NBA Finals after he took the helm in early 1984, the Celtics and Lakers won all five titles, each missing the decisive series just once.

Current commissioner Adam Silver recalled the anecdote last June, ahead of the 2025 NBA Finals, by which time the league was guaranteed a seventh different champion in seven years. ‚ÄúWe set out to create a system that allowed for more competition around the league,‚Äù Silver said then in his annual news conference. ‚ÄúThe goal being to have 30 teams all in the position, if well managed, to compete for championships. And that‚Äôs what we‚Äôre seeing here.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe goal isn‚Äôt necessarily to have a different champion every year,‚Äù Silver added. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs to have [...] parity of opportunity.‚Äù

NFL commissioner Roger Goodell gave his own endorsement of competitive parity in 2011: ‚ÄúThere are systems that we have to make sure that we maintain. When you come into a season, every fan thinks that their football team has a chance to win the Super Bowl.‚Äù

When the Los Angeles Dodgers loaded up on talent yet again before the 2025 MLB season, seemingly fated to repeat as champions, commissioner Rob Manfred acknowledged that, ‚ÄúWe certainly have owners in the game who are as concerned as fans are about the level of disparity in the game.‚Äù

For decades, the heads of American sports leagues have argued that parity is necessary to sustain fan interest and to stay financially sustainable. And they have manipulated the talent market in all sorts of ways ‚Äì with salary caps, revenue sharing, drafts, wealth and talent redistribution, ‚Äúaprons‚Äù, and so on ‚Äì in service of that goal.

Yet the competitiveness of a league has no obvious bearing on its popularity. Baseball was never more popular than when the New York Yankees dominated it. The NBA‚Äôs cultural ascent coincided with the Celtics and Lakers‚Äô decade-long duopoly, followed by the Chicago Bulls dynasty. Manchester United won the Premier League just about every year as the circuit became globally dominant.

Concerned about sustainability? Don‚Äôt be. Professional teams that lost money often double as handy instruments to write off taxes for billionaires while the asset steadily appreciates anyway. To a cynic, parity has always felt like an excuse to short-change the players, a contrived cover for cost-controls and labor suppression.

Lately, the flaws in the parity principle have been delightfully illustrated by the Premier League, the sports world‚Äôs ongoing experiment to determine what happens when virtually no brakes are applied to runaway globalized capitalism. Past the halfway point of this season, just nine points separate fourth-place Liverpool from 15th-place Bournemouth. Sixth-place Newcastle are three points from 12th-place Everton. In sum, seven teams sit within the swing of a single game. Which is to say that with no parity mechanisms whatsoever, almost all the teams in the league are competitive.

They can‚Äôt all win the thing, exactly, but through an ever-evolving class of owners who treat their Premier League clubs as anything from vanity projects to investment vehicles to soft-power plays, a broad upper class and a huge middle class of teams have emerged.

The league‚Äôs largely unfettered economics ‚Äì with the profitability and sustainability rules now tweaked to merely limit clubs to spending no more than 85 percent of their footballing earnings on their squads ‚Äì practically require every club to spend at a competitive level every single season. This has caused a flattening of the talent level between many teams, and forced the smaller clubs to get smarter and better. In either case, the situation stands in stark contrast to the American system, in which many parasite teams allowed to feed off their more ambitious peers.

Meanwhile, the Premier League‚Äôs 20 teams are trending towards more competitive balance. Liverpool‚Äôs 84-point title last season was the lowest haul since Leicester City‚Äôs fluky (if thrilling) championship in 2015-16, when all the habitual contenders happened to have an off-year at exactly the same time.

More tellingly, perhaps, is the uptick in the average points total of the middle third, give or take, of the Premier League table in the past four seasons and change. In 2021-22, the clubs who finished eighth through 13th averaged 49.5 points over the course of the campaign. That number ticked up by half a point over the next two seasons, before jumping to 54.7 in 2024-25. So far, 2025-26 is on pace to post a figure of 53.7, suggesting that something lasting may be shifting. (The 2020-21 season did produce a 54-point average, but that was a significant outlier to the three seasons before and after it.)

Certainly, you could point out that this competitive balance may exist organically in the Premier League but eludes almost every other league in the world, save for Italy‚Äôs Serie A. But then the closest comparator to the Premier League in our little parity case study isn‚Äôt the European continent‚Äôs legacy soccer leagues. It‚Äôs the other best-in-class, globally popular circuits that dominate their sports: the NFL, the NBA and MLB.

At least a half-dozen Premier League teams, and as many as eight, have the resources to mount a plausible title challenge in any given season. That‚Äôs about a third of the league. Three-quarters of the top-tier clubs stand a reasonable chance of finishing in the top half or better.

That‚Äôs a kind of parity, too. Yet it was achieved without manipulating the market to the detriment of the players and, ultimately, the product.

Leander Schaerlaeckens‚Äô book on the United States men‚Äôs national soccer team, The Long Game, is out on 12 May. You can preorder it here. He teaches at Marist University.

title: The Athletic‚Äôs top 15 leaders in sports
description: Leadership is the invisible currency of sports. Hard to quantify, but impossible to win without. The Athletic surveyed over 100 industry insiders to find the figures who command the most respect in 2025. From tacticians to culture-setters, these are the‚Ä¶
fullText:
Leadership is the invisible currency of sports. Hard to quantify, but impossible to win without. The Athletic surveyed over 100 industry insiders to find the figures who command the most respect in 2025. From tacticians to culture-setters, these are the names that define the modern standard. Here are the top 15 most admired leaders.

Role:¬†Quarterback, Kansas City Chiefs‚Äã
Mahomes makes the list because his leadership is as effortless as his playmaking. He balances supreme confidence with a calming presence that stabilizes the entire franchise when chaos hits. He isn‚Äôt just the face of the Chiefs; he is the league‚Äôs competitive north star.‚Äã

Role:¬†President of Basketball Operations, Boston Celtics‚Äã
Transitioning from the sideline to the front office, Stevens proved that elite basketball IQ translates anywhere. He is admired for his cold, decisive roster management, prioritizing winning combinations over sentimentality. His vision turned a good team into a perennial juggernaut.‚Äã

Role:¬†Head Coach (Former)‚Äã
Carroll‚Äôs legacy is built on a high-energy, positive culture that allowed players to be themselves. His ‚Äúalways compete‚Äù mantra wasn‚Äôt just a slogan; it was a daily way of life that resonated across generations of athletes. He remains the blueprint for the modern players‚Äô coach.‚Äã

Role:¬†Quarterback, Philadelphia Eagles‚Äã
Hurts commands respect through a stoic demeanor that never fluctuates, regardless of the scoreboard. His leadership is quiet but heavy, grounded in a relentless work ethic that sets the temperature for the entire building. In a volatile market, he is the unshakeable constant.‚Äã

Role:¬†Head Coach, Michigan State‚Äã
The ultimate throwback, Izzo leads with a mix of brutal accountability and genuine, familial love. His teams mirror his identity: tough, physical, and built to survive the grind of March. Peers admire him for the fierce loyalty he inspires in everyone who wears the jersey.‚Äã

Role:¬†Head Coach, Pittsburgh Steelers‚Äã
Tomlin is the master of messaging, known for cutting through the noise with honesty that players crave. His greatest skill is his consistency; he prevents the floor from dropping out, no matter the roster turnover. He remains the standard for stability in the NFL.‚Äã

Role:¬†Forward, Las Vegas Aces‚Äã
Wilson has become the WNBA‚Äôs undisputed face, carrying the league‚Äôs growth with grace and dominance. She leads with accessibility and humor, anchoring a dynasty while shouldering the expectations of a superstar. She makes greatness look relatable.‚Äã

Role:¬†Head Coach, Detroit Lions‚Äã
Campbell turned a punchline into a powerhouse by doubling down on authenticity and grit. He proved that vulnerability can be a strength, building a locker room that fights harder because they truly believe in the man leading them. His team is a direct reflection of his heart.‚Äã

Role:¬†Head Coach, USWNT‚Äã
Hayes brings a psychological edge to management, treating athletes as whole people to unlock their best performance. Her rapid success with Chelsea and the USWNT on the international stage showcased her ability to diagnose and fix culture instantly. She is a tactician who understands the human element first.‚Äã

Role:¬†General Manager, OKC Thunder‚Äã
Presti is the long-game visionary who wasn‚Äôt afraid to look foolish in the short term to build something lasting. His disciplined approach to asset accumulation set a new template for success in small markets. He wins by sticking to the plan when others panic.‚Äã

Role:¬†Head Coach, Kansas City Chiefs‚Äã
Reid is the rare genius who lacks an ego, creating a collaborative environment where players‚Äô personalities thrive. His offensive creativity is legendary, but his steady, fatherly hand is what keeps the dynasty humming. He makes the grind of football feel like a joyride.‚Äã

Role:¬†Head Coach, UConn‚Äã
Auriemma demands a level of perfectionism that most programs can‚Äôt comprehend. His abrasive style works because it is rooted in a deep, relentless drive to extract every ounce of potential from his players. To play for him is to ‚Äã

Role:¬†Point Guard, Golden State Warriors‚Äã
Curry‚Äôs leadership is defined by ‚Äújoyful energy,‚Äù a selfless vibe that allowed a dynasty to breathe without ego battles. He is the rare alpha who invites others to share the spotlight rather than hoarding it. His presence dissolves tension and elevates everyone.‚Äã

Role:¬†Head Coach, South Carolina‚Äã
Staley is a ‚Äútruth-teller‚Äù who advocates fiercely for her players and the sport itself. She built a powerhouse by being a mentor first and a coach second, earning unshakeable trust from her roster. Her voice resonates far beyond the court.‚Äã

Role:¬†Head Coach, Golden State Warriors‚Äã
Kerr tops the list for his mastery of the soft skills, managing massive egos and keeping a dynasty hungry over a decade. His leadership is defined by emotional intelligence and perspective, keeping the game in balance for his team. He is the ultimate people manager.‚Äã

These fifteen leaders share one trait: the ability to make those around them better. Whether through tactical brilliance or emotional connection, they set the bar that the rest of the sports world chases.‚Äã

title: 'No desire' for World Cup boycott over Greenland
description: The French government is not currently in favour of boycotting this summer's World Cup over US President Donald Trump's threats to annex Greenland, according to the country's sports minister.
fullText:
The French government is not currently in favour of boycotting this summer's World Cup over US President Donald Trump's threats to annex Greenland, according to the country's sports minister.

France is among eight European countries which Trump has said he may impose tariffs on for opposing his demand to take over the autonomous territory, which is controlled by Denmark.

"As it stands now, there is no desire from the ministry for a boycott of this great competition," Marina Ferrari said.

"Now, I will not anticipate what could happen, but I have also heard voices raised from certain political blocs.

"I am one who believes in keeping sport separate [from politics]. The World Cup is an extremely important moment for those who love sport."

She was speaking before Trump said on Wednesday that he is seeking "immediate negotiations" to acquire Greenland for national security reasons, but that he "won't use force". His pursuit of the mineral-rich Arctic territory has caused growing tensions with European allies.

Denmark could play in the World Cup - which will see 78 of the 104 matches staged in the US - if its team qualifies via play-offs.

In a statement, the chief executive of the Danish Football Association, Erik Brogger Rasmussen, told BBC Sport: "We are, of course, aware of the current sensitive situation.

"Like many others, we are following it closely on an ongoing basis. Our focus right now is on winning the two matches in March and thereby qualifying for the World Cup."

title: Women coaches 'twice as likely to be bullied', study finds
description: Women who coach sports in the UK are experiencing bullying and harassment at far higher rates than men, according to a new study.
fullText:
Women who coach sports in the UK are experiencing bullying and harassment at far higher rates than men, according to a new study.

The survey of 2,000 coaches conducted by the charity Women in Sport and Leeds Beckett University found 30% of women surveyed said they had experienced bullying in coaching environments, compared with 15% of men.

Women also reported higher levels of harassment, with 21% saying they had experienced it compared with 12% of men, while they also faced more aggression or violence, affecting 22% of women compared with 19% of men surveyed.

The report said "sports coaching in the UK is a hostile environment for women", many of who "choose to walk away" from "a system that offers less security, less support and greater risks".

The study found the perpetrators of harassment of women coaches are mostly fellow coaches, while aggression and intimidation most often came from parents.

It adds that bullying becomes more severe the higher women progress, as 26% of women reported bullying at grassroots level, followed by 38% in talent pathways and 46% in high‚Äëperformance settings, where women are heavily outnumbered.

Men are almost twice as likely as women to hold permanent full‚Äëtime coaching roles, while women are more often unpaid, on zero‚Äëhours contracts or working without formal agreements.

Only 12% of women say they receive regular feedback, despite 41% of workforce leaders saying feedback is routinely given.

Women are 18% less likely than men to feel their opinions are heard and respected, with the gap widening in talent pathway and high‚Äëperformance settings.

Women are more likely to avoid perpetrators than report them, despite 95% of organisations claiming zero‚Äëtolerance policies, because of low trust in current reporting systems.

title: Inter Milan Vice-President On New Stadium: ‚ÄúImportant It‚Äôs Still In The San Siro District‚Äù
description: Inter Milan vice-president Javier Zanetti delivered his verdict on the San Siro project and shared his hopes for the future.Speaking to Sky Sports UK via FCInterNews, Zanetti shared his thoughts about...
fullText:
Inter Milan vice-president Javier Zanetti delivered his verdict on the San Siro project and shared his hopes for the future.

Speaking to Sky Sports UK via FCInterNews, Zanetti shared his thoughts about the club‚Äôs intention to build a state-of-the-art stadium.

AC Milan and Inter have embarked on their new stadium project after acquiring the land from the city.

Indeed, a brand-new stadium forms a key pillar of Oaktree‚Äôs long-term vision for the Nerazzurri.

Therefore, the clubs have earmarked substantial funds to finance this history-defining development.

Both teams are aiming to create a modern arena that will serve as a cornerstone for generations to come.

Meanwhile, renowned British architect Norman Foster will be in charge of construction, with the new stadium expected to open in 2031.

As such, there‚Äôs a good probability that San Siro will be among the venues to host the UEFA Euro 2032.

MILAN, ITALY ‚Äì APRIL 23: General view outside the stadium prior to the coppa Italia Semi Final match between FC Internazionale and AC Milan at Stadio Giuseppe Meazza San Siro on April 23, 2025 in Milan, Italy. (Photo by Marco Luzzani/Getty Images)

‚ÄúThe Meazza will always be a stadium that brings back memories. And it has brought many victories,‚Äù Javier Zanetti said.

‚ÄúEverything has changed,‚Äù he added. ‚ÄúI believe that a top club like Inter, known worldwide, needs a new, state-of-the-art stadium.

‚ÄúThe important thing is that it‚Äôs always at San Siro. I hope we‚Äôll be able to create special memories there as well.‚Äù

Finally, Zanetti named his most memorable game in the Nerazzurri shirt.

‚ÄúMy debut game,‚Äù he claimed. ‚ÄúI could never have imagined it would be the first of 858 matches.‚Äù

Zanetti spent his entire professional career in Europe at Inter. Indeed, he joined the club in 1995 and stayed here until 2014.

Upon retirement, the Nerazzurri retired his No.4 jersey, paying tribute to one of the most iconic figures in club history.

However, Zanetti couldn‚Äôt stay away from his beloved Inter, returning to the club in a different capacity shortly after hanging up his boots.

title: Yahoo Sports' way-too-early Top 25 for 2026 season
description: The 2025 season is hardly over. That's not stopping us from looking eight months ahead.
fullText:
The 2025 season just barely ended, but that's not stopping us from looking eight months ahead.

Here's our way-too-early top 25 for the 2026 college football season. A lot can and will change in the months before the season begins in late August. But here's our quick and undoubtedly wrong look at how the field could stack up.

How do the Cavaliers follow up the best season in school history? Tony Elliott signed QBs Beau Pribula (Missouri) and Eli Holstein (Pitt) to replace Chandler Morris along with a few key defenders from the transfer portal. Virginia should be near the top of the ACC again.

QB Luke Altmyer is out of eligibility and Bret Bielema brought in former East Carolina QB Katin Houser to replace him. The addition of FIU WR Alex Perry could be significant too. He had 56 grabs for 840 yards in 2025. This is a team that‚Äôs won 19 games over the past two seasons and should again be safely bowl eligible.

The Huskies dodged a huge loss when Demond Williams Jr. decided he was going to stay for the 2026 season. Williams can enter the season as a sleeper Heisman candidate and is the reason why we have Washington ranked. If he had left, coach Jedd Fisch would have had a huge hole to fill at QB.

Is it a make-or-break season for Shane Beamer? Yes, the Gamecocks had a rough schedule in 2025, but the defense took a step back and the offensive line was rough. SC added NC State OL Jacarrius Peak in the transfer portal and QB LaNorris Sellers is back along with edge rusher Dylan Stewart.

Did Houston have the quietest 10-win season in 2025? QB Conner Weigman is back for a second season after he threw for over 2,700 yards and 25 TDs and the Cougars have added a very solid transfer class. The team‚Äôs top two signees are offensive linemen and former Tulane RB Makhi Hughes comes over from Oregon where he hopes to recapture the form he had with the Green Wave.

We‚Äôre already bullish on the quick turnaround James Franklin can engineer in Blacksburg. He‚Äôs brought over a host of transfers from Penn State, including QB Ethan Grunkemeyer and TE Luke Reynolds along with CB Jaquez White from Troy and edge rusher Javion Hilson from Missouri.

Can Lincoln Kienholz have a breakout season with the Cardinals? After multiple seasons as a backup at Ohio State, Kienholz is now the favorite to start at QB. Coach Jeff Brohm kept RB Isaac Brown from entering the transfer portal and also added Vanderbilt WR Tre Richardson.

As many former Nittany Lions have gone to Virginia Tech, even more Iowa State players have followed Matt Campbell to State College. That includes QB Rocco Becht, RB Carson Hansen, CB Jeremiah Cooper and a bunch of others. Building a team out of Iowa State players isn‚Äôt flashy, but Campbell is the winningest coach in school history for a reason.

The Mustangs bring back QB Kevin Jennings and added former Cal RB Kendrick Raphael in the transfer portal. He rushed for 943 yards and 13 scores in 2025. The loss of offensive coordinator Casey Woods could hurt ‚Äî he‚Äôs the new head coach at Missouri State ‚Äî but Rhett Lashlee‚Äôs offense should be one of the best in the ACC once again.

It‚Äôs hard to see how Michigan could have done much better than getting Kyle Whittingham after it fired Sherrone Moore. Whittingham brings offensive coordinator Jason Beck with him from Utah and Bryce Underwood could have a breakout season under Beck. DE John Henry Daley and other players have followed Whittingham from Salt Lake City, too.

The Cougars lost defensive coordinator Jay Hill after Whittingham hired him at Michigan and replaced Hill with longtime assistant Kelly Poppinga. QB Bear Bachmeier should be even better in 2026 and getting leading rusher LJ Martin back for his senior year is a big boost.

The Trojans have the top-ranked recruiting class in the country heading into the 2026 season. How many of those players can make an immediate impact? Lincoln Riley‚Äôs offense will be very good once again. The onus is on the defense ‚Ä¶ again. The Trojans haven‚Äôt allowed fewer than 5.5 yards per play since it gave up 5.4 yards a play in 2018 under Clay Helton.

We‚Äôre betting on a full offseason of health for John Mateer. He‚Äôs back for another run at it with the Sooners and was fantastic before he suffered a broken bone in his throwing hand in Week 4 against Auburn. OU‚Äôs defense was good enough to win a national title in 2025, but the offense simply wasn‚Äôt in the second half of the season.

With Ty Simpson off to the NFL, it‚Äôs up to Austin Mack or Keelon Russell to start at QB for the Crimson Tide. Mack has more familiarity with Kalen DeBoer and Ryan Grubb‚Äôs offensive system. Russell is a former five-star recruit. The Tide also bring in No. 1 running back recruit Ezavier Crowell. Can he make Alabama‚Äôs run game work again?

Let‚Äôs be clear: This ranking is betting on Trinidad Chambliss winning his legal fight to get a sixth year of eligibility from the NCAA. The Rebels are clear contenders to get back to the College Football Playoff if he‚Äôs back in Oxford. If he‚Äôs not, there are major questions at quarterback after Austin Simmons transferred to Missouri.

Just like with Ole Miss, we‚Äôre doing a bit of quarterback projection here and assuming that Darian Mensah ends up a Hurricane. If he doesn‚Äôt, then adjust your expectations accordingly. A young secondary should get even better in 2026 and Malachi Toney will be a sleeper Heisman candidate.

QB CJ Carr got better as the season went on in 2025 and could be one of the best quarterbacks in college football in 2026. The Irish made some late moves in the transfer portal, have the No. 2 high school recruiting class in the country and, most importantly, coach Marcus Freeman rebuffed NFL interest to stay in South Bend.

The Aggies bring back QB Marcel Reed, RB Le‚ÄôVeon Moss and WR Mario Craver. They also have On3‚Äôs No. 3 transfer portal class as they‚Äôve loaded up on defense. Five of the Aggies‚Äô top six rated transfers are all on that side of the ball, including former Tennessee QB Rickey Gibson and former Northwestern edge rusher Anto Saka.

Raiding the transfer portal worked really well for Texas Tech ahead of the 2025 season. Why not do it again and add a QB this time? Brendan Sorsby comes over from Cincinnati and Texas Tech is reloading up front again after the success that its defensive line had in 2025.

Lane Kiffin got his quarterback in former Arizona State signal-caller Sam Leavitt. He also added former five-star recruit Husan Longstreet from USC. LSU was one of the biggest underachievers in 2025. This is a roster that can make the College Football Playoff. And, given the way Kiffin left Ole Miss, anything less than making the CFP semifinals can be considered a disappointment.

QB Gunner Stockton is set to come back after he finished in the top 10 of the Heisman voting. The Bulldogs need to replace Zachariah Branch and CJ Allen, but this is a team loaded with top-tier recruits. Even though Georgia has lost in the quarterfinals in each of the past two seasons, we‚Äôre not betting against Kirby Smart‚Äôs team anytime soon.

QB Julian Sayin and WR Jeremiah Smith are back as the Buckeyes are now the chasers in the Big Ten once again. Losing Sonny Styles, Arvell Reese and Caleb Downs on defense is significant, but Matt Patricia‚Äôs unit was so, so good in 2025 that it‚Äôs hard to see them taking a huge step back in 2026.

The Hoosiers have become one of the best teams at navigating the transfer portal and they have the top class in the country in 2026 after winning the national championship this season. Former TCU QB Josh Hoover is in line to replace Fernando Mendoza and WR Nick Marsh is a stellar add from Michigan State. Don‚Äôt overlook the edge rushing depth that Curt Cignetti signed as well.

Get ready for another offseason of Texas talk. Don‚Äôt say you haven‚Äôt been warned. The Longhorns have loaded up on offense for what could be QB Arch Manning‚Äôs final season. RBs Raleek Brown and Hollywood Smothers arrived via the transfer portal along with former Auburn WR Cam Coleman. Oh, the defense is coordinated by Will Muschamp again, too. How good can he make that unit?

The return of Dante Moore for the 2026 season isn‚Äôt the only reason the Ducks are in this spot. Yes, Oregon loses TE Kenyon Sadiq, S Dillon Thieneman and LB Bryce Boettcher, but Matayo Uiagalelei is back along the defensive line along with A‚ÄôMauri Washington and Bear Alexander. RB Jordon Davison should be better as a sophomore and Oregon added Minnesota S Koi Perich in the transfer portal too.

title: ESPN And Words + Pictures Announce Docuseries On Nick Saban, College Football‚Äôs Coaching GOAT
description: As ESPN readies to air the College Football Playoff National Championship game, the sports network is announcing plans for a documentary series on the coach who has won more national championships than anyone else ‚Äì Nick Saban. The six-part series titled Saban, from ESPN and Word + Pictures, is directed by Russell Dinallo and produced ‚Ä¶
fullText:
As ESPN readies to air the College Football Playoff National Championship game, the sports network is announcing plans for a documentary series on the coach who has won more national championships than anyone else ‚Äì Nick Saban.

The six-part series titled Saban, from ESPN and Word + Pictures, is directed by Russell Dinallo and produced by Words + Pictures‚Äô Connor Schell, Libby Geist, Aaron Cohen, and Alexa Conway along with Tom Rinaldi, with Gabe Honig serving as co-executive producer and showrunner. It will document the man who won seven college football national championships ‚Äì one at LSU and six at the University of Alabama.

College Football Playoff National Championship: How To Watch Indiana Vs. Miami On TV & Online

NFL Playoffs Schedule: How To Watch All Divisional Round Games Live Online & On TV

Dish Countersues Disney In Fight Over Sling TV Passes

Watch a teaser for the Saban series below.

‚ÄúThe series will peel back the curtain on the long closely guarded world of Saban,‚Äù notes a release, ‚Äúwith hundreds of hours of never-before-seen footage from the locker room and practice fields, as well as many other behind-the-scenes moments in his career at Alabama, and prior to that LSU, the Miami Dolphins, and Michigan State among other stops. There‚Äôs also a wealth of present-day interviews with Saban and his wife, the legendary Ms. Terry Saban, whose own influence and impact played a massive role in Nick‚Äôs success as a coach and leader.‚Äù

Saban retired two years ago from Alabama and now serves as an ESPN analyst ‚Äì as well as a pitchman for Aflac and Vrbo.

‚ÄúWith my coaching days behind me, Ms. Terry and I have been doing a lot of reflection and realized we were ready to tell our story,‚Äù Nick Saban said. ‚ÄúThe team at Words + Pictures has encouraged me to really look back not just at my time at Alabama, but every stop along the way ‚Äì and not just reflect on what happened but consider the process which made it happen. I interacted with a lot of players and coaches along the way and I‚Äôm happy to see that so many of them have contributed to this docuseries. There‚Äôs a lot to tell, and I‚Äôm excited to share it all.‚Äù

In addition to his national titles, Saban‚Äôs football programs produced four Heisman Trophy winners and innumerable NFL stars. ESPN says the series will include ‚Äúmore than 30 hours of interviews with Saban, and more than 80 interviews with former players, assistant coaches, rivals, family, friends, and observers, the series offers a rare look at how he became the most successful and influential figure that the game of college football has ever known.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere will never be another Nick Saban,‚Äù observed Connor Schell, CEO of Words + Pictures. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a football genius, a singular leader, and a true icon who has done more than anyone to shape the modern game of college football and the culture around it. When you work with Coach Saban, you‚Äôre constantly reminded how every small detail matters and, in his case, that attention to detail and process has added up to an incredible journey and legacy. Working with Coach Saban and Ms. Terry has been a tremendous experience, and we can‚Äôt wait to share their story with the world.‚Äù

ESPN says the premiere date and full rollout plans for the series will be announced at a later date.

title: Manchester City complete Marc Guehi signing
description: Manchester City have signed England defender Marc Guehi (25) from Crystal Palace in a deal worth an initial ¬£20m, as reported by Sky Sports.The 25-year-old has agreed a five-and-a-half-year contract ...
fullText:
Manchester City have signed England defender Marc Guehi (25) from Crystal Palace in a deal worth an initial ¬£20m, as reported by Sky Sports.

The 25-year-old has agreed a five-and-a-half-year contract at the Etihad Stadium, keeping him at City until 2031, with the deal also including a sell-on clause for Palace.

City moved for Guehi after suffering a number of injuries in defence. The centre-back was out of contract at the end of the season and had been close to joining Liverpool last summer, while Arsenal and Bayern Munich were also interested.

‚ÄúI am really happy and incredibly proud to be a Manchester City player,‚Äù said Guehi. ‚ÄúI am now at the best club in England and part of an unbelievable squad. I can‚Äôt wait to get started.‚Äù

City manager Pep Guardiola said the transfer was only possible because of Guehi‚Äôs contract situation, with several clubs hoping to sign him on a free transfer in the summer. He praised Guehi‚Äôs quality and versatility, saying he can play on either side of central defence.

The former Chelsea defender becomes City‚Äôs second January signing following the arrival of forward Antoine Semenyo from Bournemouth. City‚Äôs spending over the past 12 months now stands at around ¬£445m.

Crystal Palace manager Oliver Glasner criticised the timing of the move, saying his side were ‚Äúcompletely abandoned‚Äù by the club‚Äôs hierarchy after selling their captain so close to a match.

Guehi leaves Palace having established himself as one of the Premier League‚Äôs most reliable defenders and a regular for England. For City, he arrives as an experienced option who can make an immediate impact as they continue to compete on multiple fronts.

title: Williams‚Äô, Joyce‚Äôs career nights lift Yotes to 75-55 win over Denver
description: VERMILLION, S.D. (USD) ‚Äì A near wire-to-wire victory for South Dakota women‚Äôs basketball Saturday afternoon, leading for 37:47 in a 75-55 victory over Denver on Native American Heritage Day in the Sanford Coyote Sports Center. Four Coyotes scored in double figures, led by a career-high 21 points by Patience Williams. She also had 13 rebounds for [‚Ä¶]
fullText:
VERMILLION, S.D. (USD) ‚Äì A near wire-to-wire victory for South Dakota women‚Äôs basketball Saturday afternoon, leading for 37:47 in a 75-55 victory over Denver on Native American Heritage Day in the Sanford Coyote Sports Center.

Four Coyotes scored in double figures, led by a career-high 21 points by¬†Patience Williams. She also had 13 rebounds for her second double-double of the season.

The Coyotes held Denver under 40% shooting in each quarter and won all four quarters. Denver scored a quick two to start the game, but USD look the lead a couple of possessions later and didn‚Äôt look back. The Coyotes hit three triples in each of the first two quarters to open up a 37-22 halftime lead.

With 4:58 to go in the third quarter,¬†Molly Joyce¬†buried a three-pointer to get to 13 points on the night, and to 1,000 in her collegiate career. She reached 1,000 career points in just 78 games, with 774 of those points coming in 59 games at Truman State. She finished with 15 points on the day, a fifth consecutive game of 15-plus.

The Coyotes kept control down the stretch, not allowing Denver within 10 of the lead for the entire second half. The Pioneers shot 31.6% from the field and 22.2% from three, but under their season averages.

Outside of Williams‚Äô double-double, Joyce was second on the Coyotes in scoring Saturday with 15.¬†Elise Turrubiates¬†tallied 13 points and¬†Tori Schlagel¬†10. Going up against her former team for the first time,¬†Angelina Robles¬†tallied nine points, six rebounds, six assists, three steals, and zero turnovers.

South Dakota outrebounded Denver 41-37, and had more points off turnovers, points in the paint, second chance points, and bench points.

The Coyotes are now 14-5 on the season and 4-1 in Summit League play, marking the program‚Äôs best start to league play since the 2022-23 season. Saturday is also USD‚Äôs 23rd¬†win over the Pioneers in program history, the second most Summit League wins over a current conference foe (Omaha, 24), and was USD‚Äôs 60th¬†Summit League victory inside the Sanford Coyote Sports Center.

The Coyotes are on the road for two games next week, starting with a trip to Omaha Thursday night for a 6:30 p.m. start.

NOTABLES
‚Ä¢ South Dakota is 14-5 on the season, 8-2 at home, and 4-1 in Summit League play.
‚Ä¢ The Coyotes are now 60-14 in Summit League play inside the Sanford Coyote Sports Center.
‚Ä¢ South Dakota is now 23-5 all-time against Denver, and 12-2 in Vermillion.
‚Ä¢¬†Patience Williams¬†recorded her second double-double of the season with a career-high 21-points and adding 13 rebounds.
‚Ä¢¬†Molly Joyce¬†eclipsed 1,000 career points in the win, scoring 15 Saturday.
‚Ä¢¬†Angelina Robles¬†recorded nine points, six rebounds, six assists, three steals in the win.
‚Ä¢¬†Elise Turrubiates¬†tallied 13 points and¬†Tori Schlagel¬†added 10 more, giving USD four players in double figures for the first time since the final non-conference game against College of Saint Mary on December 30.
‚Ä¢ Saturday was USD‚Äôs 11th¬†win of the season by 20 or more.

title: Game Preview: Columbus Blue Jackets @ Pittsburgh Penguins 1/17/26
description: Who: Columbus Blue Jackets (21-19-7, 49 points, 7th place Metropolitan Division) @ Pittsburgh Penguins (22-14-10, 54 points, 3rd place Metropolitan Division) When: 7:00 p.m. ET How to Watch: Locally televised on SportsNet Pittsburgh and FanDuel Sports Network Ohio, streaming on ESPN+ Pens‚Äô Path Ahead: This is the last game the Penguins will be playing in Pittsburgh for almost two [‚Ä¶]
fullText:
Who:¬†Columbus Blue Jackets¬†(21-19-7, 49 points, 7th place Metropolitan Division) @¬†Pittsburgh Penguins¬†(22-14-10, 54 points, 3rd place Metropolitan Division)

How to Watch: Locally televised on SportsNet Pittsburgh and FanDuel Sports Network Ohio, streaming on ESPN+

Pens‚Äô Path Ahead: This is the last game the Penguins will be playing in Pittsburgh for almost two weeks. The Pens are about to take off on a West Coast road swing through Seattle, Calgary, Edmonton and Vancouver over the next eight days, starting with a 5 p.m. ET Monday game against the Kraken.

Opponent Track: The Jackets are heading into the weekend on a three-game win streak. Elvis Merzlikins had a succinct answer when asked Thursday what‚Äôs changed for the Jackets:

3 wins in a row what‚Äôs different for the Blue Jackets?

‚ÄúNew coach.‚Äù ‚Äì Elvis Merzlikins pic.twitter.com/vKvUdIOkK1

‚Äî Spittin' Chiclets (@spittinchiclets) January 16, 2026

Season Series: This marks the last time the Jackets and Pens will meet this season. All three prior games in this season series have gone to overtime, with the Penguins losing in a shootout in October but winning in overtime in November and earlier this month.

Hidden Stat:¬†The Penguins are in a playoff spot in no small part thanks to their success against division opponents this season. Including their 2-0-1 record against the Blue Jackets, the Pens have gone 9-1-3 against teams in the Metropolitan Division so far this season. (Last season, Pittsburgh missed the playoffs after going 9-13-4 against division opponents).

Cole Sillinger ‚Äì Adam Fantilli ‚Äì Kirill Marchenko

Boone Jenner ‚Äì Sean Monahan ‚Äì Kent Johnson

Dmitri Voronkov ‚Äì Charlie Coyle ‚Äì Mathieu Olivier

Danton Heinen ‚Äì Brendan Gaunce ‚Äì Mikael Pyyhtia

Jake Christiansen / Erik Gudbranson

Goalies:¬†Elvis Merzlikins, Jet Greaves

Potential scratches: Denton Mateychuk (day-to-day), Egor Zamula, Zach Aston-Reese

Injured Reserve: Brendan Smith, Isac Lundestrom, Miles Wood, Mason Marchment

Blue Jackets defenseman Denton Mateychuk is day-to-day after taking a hard hit from Brandon Tanev during the Jackets‚Äô Sunday win over the Utah Mammoth. Columbus general manager Don Waddell said the team doesn‚Äôt expect the injury to be long-term.

Coaching change in Columbus: The Blue Jackets fired former coach Dean Evason last week after one and a half seasons and a 19-19-7 start to the 2025-26 campaign. Evason told The Athletic‚Äôs Aaron Portzline he was ‚Äúblindsided‚Äù by his dismissal.

The switch allowed the Jackets to bring in Rick Bowness, 70, who had most recently coached the Winnipeg Jets for two seasons from 2022 to 2024. He hasn‚Äôt been with the team for very long‚Äî he got the job offer Monday afternoon and joined the team Tuesday morning, per ESPN‚Äî but he‚Äôs since led the Jackets to wins over the Calgary Flames and Vancouver Canucks.

Bones got the boys ready to go üëä

CBJ x @PNCBank pic.twitter.com/tJ0gjt6C8V

‚Äî Columbus Blue Jackets (@BlueJacketsNHL) January 14, 2026

Kent Johnson played a season-high 20:55 during his first game with Bowness. The Jackets could be hoping to see some more production from the second-line winger if he keeps getting more playing time going forward.

Like the Penguins, the Blue Jackets have at times had a problems with holding on to late leads through the first half of the season. They blew third-period leads 15 times in their first 47 games, per Brian Hedger of the Columbus Dispatch. When asked about that habit after the Jackets held on to a comfortable lead in Thursday‚Äôs win over the Vancouver Canucks, Bowness said, per Portzline: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt even worry about it. It was before I got here. I‚Äôm just not worried about it‚Ä¶ That‚Äôs in the past. I know how I want us to play, so that‚Äôs the bottom line. And we‚Äôre building on that.‚Äù

Rickard Rakell ‚Äì Sidney Crosby ‚Äì Bryan Rust

Egor Chinakhov ‚Äì Tommy Novak ‚Äì Evgeni Malkin

Anthony Mantha ‚Äì Ben Kindel ‚Äì Justin Brazeau

Connor Dewar ‚Äì Blake Lizotte ‚Äì Noel Acciari

Parker Wotherspoon / Jack St. Ivany

Goalies:¬†Stuart Skinner and Arturs Silovs

Potential Scratches:¬†Ryan Graves, Kevin Hayes

IR:¬†Erik Karlsson, Filip Hallander, Caleb Jones, Rutger McGroarty

The Penguins had an off day Friday after Thursday‚Äôs 6-3 win over the Flyers.

Sidney Crosby has 69 points (24 goals, 45 assists) in 48 career games against the Blue Jackets, which ranked behind only Patrick Kane for the most among any active NHL player. Kris Letang meanwhile leads all NHL defensemen with 14 goals against the Blue Jackets, his highest total against any single team, per Penguins PR.

The Penguins are 14-1-4 in their last 19 games against the Blue Jackets, and they‚Äôre 16-0-2 in their last 18 games against the Jackets at home, per Penguins PR.

The Pens‚Äô special teams have been thriving lately. They‚Äôre heading into Saturday‚Äôs matchup having gone 16-for-16 on the PK over their last four games, and they‚Äôre currently ranked second in the NHL with a 29.4 percent power-play success rate.

title: Letters to Sports: Charging out of the NFL playoffs, again
description: Readers of the Los Angeles Times Sports section give their thoughts on the Chargers' playoff exit, the Dodgers signing Kyle Tucker, the, Lakers, Clippers and Chloe Kim.
fullText:
If there‚Äôs an important playoff game for the Chargers to win, you can bet they‚Äôre going to lose. Such was the case again against New England.

While having a decent enough defense, the offense was pathetic. And, yes, I know their offensive line was completely depleted. But, the 49ers were banged up as well. They lost George Kittle and still won.

Well, there‚Äôs always ‚Äúnext season.‚Äù Unfortunately, those two words still haunt the Chargers and their fans.

Once again the Chargers flop in the playoffs.

This time much of the blame should be placed at the top with Jim Harbaugh. Perhaps he did not watch or was not aware of how many times in this year's playoffs teams had failed to convert on fourth down with disastrous consequences. The psychological effect on the team from failing to convert and put points on the board early was evident. He had a team without their top running back and a very weak offensive line yet chose to go for it.

Hopefully he will learn from this or maybe it is time for Harbaugh to join his brother in seeking new jobs.

Nothing wrong with the Chargers that a new OC with a game plan can't fix. Or is there?

Thanks for firing your OC Greg Roman. Loyalty is great but loyalty does not get you to the promised land. In two postseason trips, one touchdown to show for it.

It needed to be done for Justin Herbert & Co.

The Yankees won 27 World Series championships by being the best team money can buy. The west coast Yankees, aka the Dodgers, are now the best team money can buy. That's capitalism, baby!

As a Dodgers fan for a Joe DiMaggio-esque 56 consecutive seasons, I am happy to have Kyle Tucker in the Dodgers' outfield in 2026. Certainly, he will be an improvement over Michael Conforto, and allow Teoscar Hernandez to go back to left field.

However, I find it perplexing that a player who appeared in only 78 and 136 games in 2024 and 2025, and who has had only one top 10 MVP finish (fifth in 2023) in his career, would be signed for a whopping average of $60-million annually. To earn that enormous salary over the next four seasons, Tucker should be considered the best player in baseball not named Shohei Ohtani.

Newsflash! The Dodgers buy another superstar, cost be damned! I'm not a Dodgers fan. I'm a Baseball fan, witnessing an organization job a system that destroys parity and fairplay. So go ahead ‚Äî hop aboard the Dodgers bandwagon for another championship. While baseball fans everywhere else throw up their hands in disgust and flock to the NFL.

The Dodgers' signing of Kyle Tucker for ridiculous money now ensures a (stoppage) after this baseball season. For everyone saying other teams could do the same thing, really? As much as anyone could love the Dodgers, this just takes away from the game.

If you‚Äôre mad at the Dodgers don't stop there ‚Äî might as well don a cape and be super mad because MLB has no kryptonite against them.

We should not expect too much from the Lakers. We have the same offense ran by the Dallas Mavericks for Luka Doncic transplanted to L.A. Give the ball to Luka and everyone else stands around and watch. Who is teaching these guys defense?

How many more games do fans have to endure before the Lakers hire a coach who is a defensive specialist? Where is Frank Vogel when you need him?

The only way I see the Lakers or Clippers making it to the second round of the playoffs is if they play each other in the first round.

The womens' snowboarding competition at next month's Winter Olympics in Milan has taken an interesting twist. American Chloe Kim, two-time Olympic gold medalist in the halfpipe, will have to wear a shoulder brace after tearing her labrum. This would be analogous to having one arm tied behind your back.

The Los Angeles Times welcomes expressions of all views. Letters should be brief and become the property of The Times. They may be edited and republished in any format. Each must include a valid mailing address and telephone number. Pseudonyms will not be used.

Get the best, most interesting and strangest stories of the day from the L.A. sports scene and beyond from our newsletter The Sports Report.

This story originally appeared in Los Angeles Times.

title: Chicago prepares for WNBA All-Star Weekend with a pitch to local investors and businesses: ‚ÄòDo a little more‚Äô
description: The explosive growth of women‚Äôs sports has been a well-documented phenomenon over the last four years. But when Chicago hosts the 2026 WNBA All-Star Weekend in July, Kara Bachman ‚Äî the executive director of the Chicago Sports Commission ‚Äî wants the city‚Äôs investors and businesses to do more than just cheer from the sidelines. ‚ÄúDo a little more,‚Äù Bachman said Friday during a launch event in ...
fullText:
The explosive growth of women‚Äôs sports has been a well-documented phenomenon over the last four years.

But when Chicago hosts the 2026 WNBA All-Star Weekend in July, Kara Bachman ‚Äî the executive director of the Chicago Sports Commission ‚Äî wants the city‚Äôs investors and businesses to do more than just cheer from the sidelines.

‚ÄúDo a little more,‚Äù Bachman said Friday during a launch event in Fulton Market. ‚ÄúPut your money where your mouth is.‚Äù

The league‚Äôs All-Star festivities will return to Chicago for the second time from July 23-25, with the game scheduled for Saturday, July 25 at the United Center. Those dates are more than six months away ‚Äî but planning already has begun for a cornerstone of the WNBA calendar.

The latest step of that process took place Friday in a launch event headlined by Gov. JB Pritzker, mayor Brandon Johnson and part-owner Dwyane Wade as the Sky and the city made their pitch to local investors and business leaders to take part in the weekend.

According to a report by Front Office Sports, Chicago was the only city to bid for hosting the 2026 All-Star weekend. The reticence from other teams? Hosting duties are split between the host team and the league, making the weekend an expensive affair as the standard for logistics such as hotels, parties and activations rise meteorically with the sport as a whole.

Sky co-owner and operating chair Nadia Rawlinson spearheaded the pitch for Chicago to land the event. She said the Sky are embracing the responsibility as an opportunity to highlight Chicago as a whole. While some features ‚Äî a welcoming event, sponsor activations featuring star players, an invite-only party organized in collaboration with the players union ‚Äî will be familiar from past iterations, Friday‚Äôs launch outlined a series of plans and initiatives to expand the event‚Äôs footprint.

This includes a series of VIP roundtable dinners in the months leading up to the event and an innovation summit to highlight and support advancements in women‚Äôs sports. During All-Star weekend, Rawlinson said the Sky will host a radio row to highlight prominent sports and business shows. The Sky also plan to partner with the city for a series of community initiatives around the weekend, including a project to add the WNBA 3-point line to basketball courts at every public park in Chicago.

Throughout the weekend, Rawlinson emphasized that the Sky and the WNBA will seek to highlight the diversity of the league‚Äôs fanbase.

‚ÄúThe WNBA is (a place) where everyone can find their person,‚Äù Rawlinson said. ‚ÄúThey can find connection. This is a place where typically people who don‚Äôt have a natural community can find community. This is our chance to highlight that.‚Äù

Chicago hosted the 2022 WNBA All-Star Game at Wintrust Arena ‚Äî home of the Sky. For the first time in franchise history, the team last season played two regular-season games at the United Center. The home of the NBA‚Äôs Bulls and NHL‚Äôs Blackhawks has nearly double the capacity of Wintrust‚Äôs 10,380.

title: Marcus Freeman is named as one of the top leaders in all of sports
description: Notre Dame head coach Marcus Freeman was named as one of the top leaders in all of sports according to The Athletic.
fullText:
Being a leader matters, and for Notre Dame football, it very much looks like they have one of the best in college football.

Actually, according to The Athletic (subscription required), Freeman is one of the top leaders in all of sports. In a recent poll they conducted of over 115 sports figures, each of them nominating five of their personal best. The picks consisted of players, coaches and executives, which puts even more weight on these rankings.

Freeman came in No. 20, the first college football head coach named, ahead of megastars like LA Laker LeBron James and New York Yankee Aaron Judge. There were only two other college coaches named with one other receiving multiple votes.

Former women‚Äôs basketball coach Muffet McGraw was one of the voters, as she noted ‚Äúhe puts players first, focusing on developing the whole person rather than just the athlete.‚Äù

This goes to show that Notre Dame has one of the best in the sport, and you could argue in all of sports. Freeman represents the university like he‚Äôs alum, and it‚Äôs clear the Irish have a great on leading their program.

Inspiring others by the way he leads ‚òòÔ∏è

Coach @Marcus_Freeman1 was named as one of the 40 most admired leaders in sports from 2025 in a survey of over 100 people in sports led by @TheAthletic.#GoIrish‚òòÔ∏è pic.twitter.com/FjszEviI8v

The top-ranked Red Raiders breezed past Haverling 61-24, while improving to (10-1), and celebrating a two historic moments for the [‚Ä¶]
fullText:
ALFRED, N.Y. (WETM) ‚Äì The 18 Sports Blitz returned for a special night in high school hoops.

Hornell girls basketball highlighted Friday night‚Äôs 18 Sports Blitz, with a pair of historic moments at Alfred University. The top-ranked Red Raiders breezed past Haverling 61-24, while improving to (10-1), and celebrating a two historic moments for the program. Midway through the 1st quarter of the contest, Selena Maldonado kicked off the senior night festivities, scoring an ‚Äúand one,‚Äù off of a layup. At the line, Maldonado converted the free throw to earn the 1,000th point of her high school career.

In the 2nd, fellow senior Jordyn Dyring added to Hornell‚Äôs 21-5 lead and etched her name in history. With a floater in the paint, Dyring surpassed 1,527 career points to become the all-time leading scorer for the girl‚Äôs program. The impressive record had stood since 1996, when Megan Buchanan wrapped up her high school career with the Red Raiders. Buchanan would follow up her high school success at Division I U Albany.

Buchanan was enshrined in both, the Hornell High School and Albany Athletic Hall of Fame in 2011, following an outstanding career. With the Great Danes, the Arkport native earned Female Athlete of the Year, as a member of the golf and basketball teams. On the court, Buchanan wrapped up her career 3rd in program history with 1,093 points. After her playing career, Buchanan has been serving as Senior Associate Athletic Director at Skidmore College, since 2005.

Elsewhere in high school basketball, the Horseheads girls wrapped up the STAC West Division title. The 4th-ranked Blue Raiders rolled past Ithaca 77-40. Paired with Corning‚Äôs 59-50 win over Elmira, Horseheads took the crown.

title: Global sports face challenges from 'AI slop' misinformation
description: A study by AI risk management platform Alethea into the surge in artificial intelligence-generated fake content, dubbed "AI slop," has warned sports teams, leagues and fans of the risks posed by increasingly sophisticated digital misinformation.  Retired NFL player Jason Kelce never said ‚Äã2026 Super Bowl halftime singer Bad Bunny's critics were "a bad fit for America's future".  San Francisco 49ers tight end George Kittle never ranted about slain ‚Äåconservative activist Charlie Kirk and politics in football.
fullText:
Jan 16 (Reuters) - A study by AI risk management platform Alethea into the surge in artificial intelligence-generated fake content, dubbed "AI slop," has warned sports teams, leagues and fans of the risks posed by increasingly sophisticated digital misinformation.

Retired NFL player Jason Kelce never said ‚Äã2026 Super Bowl halftime singer Bad Bunny's critics were "a bad fit for America's future".

San Francisco 49ers tight end George Kittle never ranted about slain ‚Äåconservative activist Charlie Kirk and politics in football.

However, thousands of people believed they did and that is the problem.

"Teams and players are suddenly being accused of things that are completely fabricated," Lisa Kaplan, ‚Äåfounder and CEO of Alethea, told Reuters on Friday, adding that the evolution of AI tools has made fake news a more daunting challenge.

"Content now looks real and is produced at a volume that makes it hard for the average person to determine if it's authentic," she said.

"Before, fake news often relied on human labour to repetitively copy and paste content. Today, AI can impersonate brands and create engaging images that mimic genuine announcements."

Kaplan noted that this wave of AI-generated misinformation has disrupted the traditional monetisation ‚Å†model of sports media. "These networks drive engagement to questionable websites, ‚Äåskew advertising metrics, and can even create scenarios that could manipulate betting markets," she added.

C Shawn Eib, Alethea's Head of Investigations, described how these networks use tactics such as making multiple disjointed announcements, like the conflicting claims that former Baltimore Ravens coach ‚ÄçJohn Harbaugh had been hired by multiple teams at the same time.

"When a single figure appears to be linked with several teams at the same time, it quickly becomes clear that an AI system is behind the creation of these images," Eib explained.

AI DECEPTION CAN EXPLOIT 'RAGE BAIT'

The content follows a formula: fake game updates, nonexistent celebrity feuds, manufactured scandals, and politicised ‚Äãquotes falsely attributed to star players.

The fabricated Kelce and Kittle quotes are prime examples. Both NFL stars publicly denied making comments they never said after the ‚Äåposts went viral.

"If fans, players and even entire franchises fall prey to these manipulated narratives, it risks damaging reputations, undermining trust and even politicising sport," Alethea's VP of Communications Kaila Ryan said.

"Sports organisations need to proactively manage their brands and digital safety. It is crucial for teams and leagues to start monitoring these risks, work together across communications, legal and security teams, and educate fans to verify announcements from official channels," she added.

The business impact extends beyond reputational harm.

These networks siphon ad revenue from legitimate sports media and distort audience metrics. Some outbound links have been flagged for phishing and malicious redirects, presenting real fraud risk to fans.

The problem ‚Å†is not limited to the NFL. Alethea discovered similar operations targeting the NBA, WNBA, MLB, NHL, ‚ÄãNASCAR, Formula 1, IndyCar and professional tennis.

Kaplan added that beyond monetisation, sport remains a rare cultural ‚Äãtouchpoint that unites people, making them attractive targets for influence operations, and she pointed to Russia's alleged exploitation of then-49ers quarterback Colin Kaepernick's 2018 'Take a Knee' protest as a precedent.

In a 2019 report, the Senate Intelligence Committee revealed that Russian trolls had focused heavily ‚Äçon the kneeling debate as part of ‚Å†a broader effort to stoke racial tensions and divide the U.S. following the 2016 election.

"Kaepernick's protests were exploited for a purpose that had nothing to do with sport. Instead, it's a way of leveraging a cultural touchstone and turning it into something that polarises people," said Kaplan.

"Teams need to ‚Å†work in unison to defend their identities and protect their fans from falling victim to fraud or manipulation," she added, noting that the best advice for fans is to be vigilant.

"Verify breaking news ‚Äåthrough official team channels, don't click links in suspicious page comments and remember that outrage is often the product, not the by-product, ‚Äåof what you're seeing".

title: San Francisco event aims to top 135,000 record crowd
description: Plans to stage the most attended event in boxing history are announced by live sports entertainment organisation iVisit Boxing (iVB).
fullText:
Plans to stage the most attended event in boxing history have been announced by live sports entertainment organisation iVisit Boxing (iVB).

San Francisco's Civic Center Plaza will be turned into an open-air boxing arena with the card being streamed on YouTube on 11 July.

The current record for the largest attendance at a boxing event stands at 135,132 - when Tony Zale and Billy Pryor fought at Juneau Park, Milwaukee in 1941.

"This world-record attempt will belong to San Francisco," said iVB chief executive Ed Pereira. "It belongs to its fans, its fighters and its communities."

"San Francisco's commitment to community and public engagement reflects iVB's belief that boxing should be built around its fans."

Despite reports that WBA, IBF and WBC heavyweight champion Oleksandr Usyk and Deontay Wilder are set to fight on the card, BBC Sport understands no agreement is in place for them to meet at this event.

title: WoW Players Love Sports, So Blizzard Is Putting A Real Tavern At NFL Game This Weekend
description:
This Sunday's NFL playoffs divisional round matchup between the New England Patriots and the Houston Texans will feature a World of Warcraft-themed attraction for tailgaters, and it's because Blizzard's data shows that its players love sports.
The World of Warcraft: Welcome Home Pre-Game Tavern, as it's called, is a marketing activation that's meant to promote WoW's upcoming Midnight expansion. Inside the tavern, people can get a drink and watch World of Warcraft livestreams. They can also meet cosplayers and influencers; the Orc cosplayers will be inside the stadium for the game itself.
The Midnight expansion adds player housing, which is something fans have been requesting for years.
