title: I've been skiing and snowboarding my whole life. Here are my 7 best tips, whether you're on the bunny hill or black diamonds.
description: After skiing and snowboarding for decades and teaching my kids the winter sports, I have great tips for first-time beginners hitting the slopes.
fullText:
I've been skiing and snowboarding my whole life, and I've even taught my children how to tackle the slopes.

Every so often, while riding the chairlift, I look down upon some out-of-control skier in soaked-through jeans, a snow-flecked sweatshirt, and cotton gloves. A few moments later, they crash into some obstacle and tangle themselves among their skis and poles.

It reminds me that although these sports can be fun winter activities, if you're not properly dressed or prepared, you're putting yourself and others at risk.

Whether you're a beginner or a seasoned pro, here are a few tips for staying safe on the mountain.

Slope safety begins at home. Before you leave, consider your outfit.

You'll definitely want waterproof snow pants and a jacket that will keep the wind and rain off of you, but your layers don't have to be anything fancy.

To start, you may be able to cobble together something warm from what you already own. Try wool sweaters, synthetic running shirts, and that random fleece vest that you own but never wear.

I think it's pointless for a new skier to drop hundreds of dollars on gear, but there are a few body parts worth investing in (hands, feet, head). If you're going to spend money on anything, invest in good gloves.

Beyond that, ski socks are priceless in keeping toes warm. A good neck gaiter and a basic pair of goggles can prevent your nose and eyes from dripping icicles, too.

When picking out your gear, keep in mind that anything made of cotton has no place on the mountain.

When cotton gets wet ‚Äî an inevitability for first-time skiers and snowboarders who spend a lot of time on the ground or anyone who's prone to sweating ‚Äî the material absorbs the moisture, remains wet, and makes you cold.

Choose synthetic materials or natural fibers like wool that help to wick away water from the body and keep you warm.

Whether you're renting or investing in your first pair of ski or snowboard boots, know that they should be snug.

The boots are meant to react to your feet's movements, so they have to be a little tight. However, they shouldn't be cutting off your circulation.

If they're uncomfortable in the rental shop, they're going to feel terrible on the mountain.

Do yourself a favor and make sure they feel as close to perfect as possible before you hit the chairlift. The employees in ski shops should be able to help.

Once you arrive at the mountain, don't look to tackle anything above your level.

If you're a beginner, head straight for the bunny slopes. There's no shame in learning to turn, stop, and not kill yourself or someone else on the mountain's gentlest run.

The fastest way to get off the bunny hill is to take a one-hour lesson to help you acquire the basic skills to become a more competent rider.

After you gain the fundamentals, progress in order. Conquering the bunny hill doesn't mean you're ready for black diamonds.

Head to green-circle beginner trails to practice your turns and technique. After getting comfortable with those skills on that terrain, try the blue-square intermediate trails.

Pro tip: Keep in mind that trail markings are not universal from mountain to mountain. A black diamond in the Poconos usually isn't as difficult as a black diamond in Colorado.

We're heading into 2026 and not the aughts ‚Äî a time when people didn't seem to truly understand that speed, hard surfaces, and bare skulls made for dangerous combinations on the slopes.

Whether you're a beginner or a pro, you'll want a helmet. You can usually rent these if needed.

Taking an in-person lesson is the best way to really get the hang of skiing, but here are a few tips and stances to get you started.

First-time skiers need to remember two foods: pizza and french fries.

Keep a gentle bend in your knees and shape your skis like a slice of pizza to achieve a more controlled stance, then proceed down the mountain at a reduced speed. Thinner pizza slices make you go faster, and wider ones slow you down.

When you're ready to go faster, shaping your skis more parallel, like french fries, will send you straight down.

Snowboarders have fewer food terms to remember, but you'll want to loosely bend your knees and carve back and forth across the mountain to limit your speed.

The trickiest part of snowboarding is shifting from your heel to your toe to change directions.

My best advice is to start slow, commit to every turn, and look where you want to go (not backward).

This story was originally published on December 3, 2024, and most recently updated on December 30, 2025.

title: In a Year of Violent Tumult, the Sports World Was Silent
description: Dave...
fullText:
In this time of unrelenting, often unprecedented cruelty and lawlessness, I‚Äôm grateful for Nation readers like you.

So many of you have taken to the streets, organized in your neighborhood and with your union, and showed up at the ballot box to vote for progressive candidates. You‚Äôre proving that it is possible‚Äîto paraphrase the legendary Patti Smith‚Äîto redeem the work of the fools running our government.

And as we head into 2026, I promise that The Nation will fight like never before for justice, humanity, and dignity in these United States.

At a time when most news organizations are either cutting budgets or cozying up to Trump by bringing in right-wing propagandists, The Nation‚Äôs writers, editors, copy editors, fact-checkers, and illustrators confront head-on the administration‚Äôs deadly abuses of power, blatant corruption, and deconstruction of both government and civil society.

We couldn‚Äôt do this crucial work without you.

Through the end of the year, a generous donor is matching all donations to The Nation‚Äôs independent journalism up to $75,000. But the end of the year is now only days away.

Time is running out to have your gift doubled. Don‚Äôt wait‚Äîdonate now to ensure that our newsroom has the full $150,000 to start the new year.

Another world really is possible. Together, we can and will win it!

title: WMBD Sports Recap: Illini, BU, ISU, ICC women all win, HS holiday tournament recap (Dec. 29, 2025)
description: Editor‚Äôs Note: The Illinois State game highlights cannot be shown on this clip because they were pulled from a game feed. PEORIA, Ill. (WMBD) ‚Äì The Illini beat Southern, Bradley defeated Evansville, and Illinois State cruised past Drake Monday. The Braves and Redbirds both stay unbeaten in MVC play. ICC women won over North Central [‚Ä¶]
fullText:
Editor‚Äôs Note: The Illinois State game highlights cannot be shown on this clip because they were pulled from a game feed.

PEORIA, Ill. (WMBD) ‚Äì The Illini beat Southern, Bradley defeated Evansville, and Illinois State cruised past Drake Monday. The Braves and Redbirds both stay unbeaten in MVC play.

ICC women won over North Central Missouri to advance to the title game of their tournament.

In high school holiday tournaments, Elmwood beat Brimfield in the Princeville tournament title game while Midland defeated Princeville in the 3rd place game. In the girls bracket, Elmwood beat Midland for the trophy and Tremont earned 3rd.

At the State Farm Holiday Classic, Normal Community boys and Washington girls advanced to their respective Large School bracket title games.

Peoria boys, U-High boys, Fieldcrest boys, and Eureka girls will settle for appearances in the third place games.

At the opening day of the Pekin tournament, Richwoods, Washington and Morton all advanced to the winner‚Äôs bracket.

In the first round of the Pontiac tournament, Manual won their opening round game to move to the quarterfinals while Bloomington and Pontiac lost.

Tremont and Dee-Mack boys will meet in the 3rd-place game of the Williamsville Holiday tournament.

Dee-Mack girls advanced to the title game at the North Mac Tournament with a 50-18 win over Pawnee.

title: Five Bears whose stock went up or down in NFL Week 17 loss to 49ers
description: Nicholas Moreano identifies five Chicago Bears players whose stock went up or down in an NFL Week 17 road loss to the San Francisco 49ers. The post Five Bears whose stock went up or down in NFL Week 17 loss to 49ers appeared first on Marquee Sports Network - Home of the Cubs, Bears, Red Stars and Sky.
fullText:
The final Sunday in 2025 provided football fans with a memorable game that featured plenty of offensive firepower.

With how the Chicago Bears and San Francisco 49ers moved the ball and scored, it felt like a game that would end with whatever team had the ball last.

Caleb Williams and the Bears had their shot with 2:15 left in the game, down by four points.

The Bears quarterback led his team on a 15-play drive that ended on the 49ers‚Äô 2-yard line after Williams attempted to extend the play to find an open receiver. With the 49ers‚Äô defense closing in, Williams threw a pass into the end zone, but it fell short.

Wild ending to an incredible game. pic.twitter.com/Xe6pJkBfEa

The Bears lost 42-38, which eliminates them from contention for the NFC‚Äôs No. 1 playoff seed. Still, as NFC North champions, they will host at least one playoff game at Soldier Field.

Here are the five players who raised and lowered their stock in the Week 17 shootout at Levi‚Äôs Stadium.

Williams had one of his best passing performances of the season, completing 25 of 42 throws for 330 yards and two touchdowns.

His first TD pass of the day ‚Äî to rookie Luther Burden III ‚Äî was a perfectly thrown 35-yard strike in the first quarter.

Caleb Williams drops it in a basket for the Luther Burden III touchdown

‚Äî Marquee Sports Network (@WatchMarquee) December 29, 2025

Williams‚Äô second TD pass ‚Äî to Colston Loveland in the second quarter‚Äì displayed some of his elite quarterback traits. Williams drew the 49ers‚Äô defense offside with his cadence, kept his eyes downfield after the snap, then threw a dart to his rookie tight end for a 36-yard score.

Caleb Williams gets the 49ers on the hard count.

Touchdown, Colston Loveland

‚Äî Marquee Sports Network (@WatchMarquee) December 29, 2025

With how well the 49ers‚Äô offense played, Williams needed to match Brock Purdy on the other side. For a majority of the game, that‚Äôs exactly what he did. However, he missed some throws.

On the final drive, Williams was heavily pressured on a first-and-10 play. He ran away from the pressure to his right but couldn‚Äôt complete a pass to wide-open Devin Duvernay on what might have been a game-winning TD.

this was 7 pic.twitter.com/WzuR5ONtEM

‚Äî Warren Sharp (@SharpFootball) December 29, 2025

It only took one play for the former All-Pro cornerback to change the game.

Johnson jumped Jauan Jennings‚Äô slant route and deflected Purdy‚Äôs first pass on the first play of the game into the air. T.J. Edwards intercepted the ball and returned it 34 yards for a pick six.

T.J. EDWARDS, PICK-SIX ON THE FIRST PLAY OF THE GAME

‚Äî Marquee Sports Network (@WatchMarquee) December 29, 2025

Johnson finished the game with zero receptions allowed on one target. He wasn‚Äôt targeted for the remainder of the game after helping cause the pick six, but he also played limited snaps in the second half.

Johnson has given up just seven receptions on 12 targets for 142 yards in six games this season, and he has one interception. It shows just how important keeping Johnson healthy is to the Bears‚Äô defense.

The Bears‚Äô rookie wide receiver returned to action after missing last week‚Äôs win over the Green Bay Packers and quickly made an impact.

Entering their third drive, the Bears had failed to record a first down. Then Williams found Burden for a 10-yard gain on second down. Three plays later, Williams connected with Burden on an explosive 35-yard TD pass, giving Chicago‚Äôs offense its first points of the game late in the first quarter.

Caleb Williams drops it in a basket for the Luther Burden III touchdown

‚Äî Marquee Sports Network (@WatchMarquee) December 29, 2025

Burden finished as the game‚Äôs leading receiver with eight receptions on nine targets for 138 yards and the TD. He was injured on the final play of the game, and head coach Ben Johnson didn‚Äôt have an immediate update on the rookie‚Äôs condition.

The Bears‚Äô veteran linebacker had the daunting task of trying to contain Christian McCaffrey. The entire defense, especially Edmunds, failed to keep the 49ers‚Äô versatile playmaker in check.

McCaffrey finished the first half with 18 carries for 121 yards and one TD. He added two receptions for 20 yards as a pass catcher before halftime.

: NBC
NFL+// https://t.co/Zkva0Y3QRRpic.twitter.com/Lw0glXcnaP

‚Äî San Francisco 49ers (@49ers) December 29, 2025

Per Pro Football Focus, Edmunds allowed seven receptions on seven targets for 55 yards and two TDs.

The 49ers‚Äô offense, which features plenty of motions and shifts, forced Edmunds and the rest of the Bears‚Äô defensive front to react slowly, and San Francisco benefited throughout the game, finishing with 496 total yards (200 rushing, 296 passing).

The Bears cornerback dealt with a hamstring injury and an illness throughout the week, but he was able to start against the 49ers.

He‚Äôs had a remarkable season, but this wasn‚Äôt a good showing. Per Pro Football Focus, Wright gave up four receptions on five targets for 73 yards in just the first half.

Wright looked a step slow and couldn‚Äôt stay in front of opposing receivers.

The post Five Bears whose stock went up or down in NFL Week 17 loss to 49ers appeared first on Marquee Sports Network - Home of the Cubs, Bears, Red Stars and Sky.

title: Falcons rumor from FOX Sports sets course for Matt Ryan reunion
description: The latest Atlanta Falcons rumor from FOX Sports sets the course for a reunion between the Falcons and former MVP quarterback Matt Ryan.
fullText:
Falcons rumor from FOX Sports sets course for Matt Ryan reunion originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

Matt Ryan was the starting quarterback of the Atlanta Falcons for nearly 15 years from 2008 to 2021, and though the 40-year-old's playing days are long over, it looks like a reunion between Ryan and the Falcons could be on the way.

According to FOX Sports' Jay Glazer, Atlanta has had conversations with Ryan about coming back to the franchise to serve in the front office. Ryan's role in the front office would be significant, and the former All-Pro signal-caller is heavily considering taking the job.

"Scoopage: Atlanta Falcons have had conversations with their former Pro Bowl QB Matt Ryan about rejoining the Falcons in a front office role. While two sides still discussing, people close to Ryan say he‚Äôs seriously considering this move and talks are ongoing. It would be for a significant role in the front office," Glazer said on X.

Ryan is a Falcons legend and clearly has an advanced football brain, as he played quarterback at a high level for multiple years and has become a respected analyst on CBS Sports since retiring in 2024.

Atlanta hasn't made the playoffs since 2017. Funny enough, Ryan was the quarterback of the last Falcons' squad that qualified for the postseason.

It's clear that change is needed for the Falcons, and though Ryan can no longer play quarterback and lead the franchise to wins, he could serve as a key piece in the front office that turns the team around.

This offseason, Atlanta will need to evaluate their quarterback room, as Michael Penix Jr. is recovering from ACL surgery¬†and Kirk Cousins is no longer a starting-caliber player. There's no better person to have in the front office with an uncertain quarterback situation than a former MVP signal-caller in Ryan.

title: üö® SGE sign star striker in record Bundesliga winter deal
description: A few days after Christmas Eve, sports director Markus Kr√∂sche gave all fans supporting Eintracht Frankfurt a belated Christmas present!As reported by 'Sky' and 'Bild' on Sunday evening, Younes Ebnou...
fullText:
A few days after Christmas Eve, sports director Markus Kr√∂sche gave all fans supporting Eintracht Frankfurt a belated Christmas present!

As reported by 'Sky' and 'Bild' on Sunday evening, Younes Ebnouatlib will transfer from SV 07 Elversberg to SGE in January. Only the medical check is pending.

The 22-year-old will cost a transfer fee of eight million euros, making him the most expensive Bundesliga transfer of this winter so far. Including bonuses, Elversberg could even receive up to ten million euros for Ebnouatlib.

The 1.91m tall striker is one of the biggest discoveries of this second division season, having scored 12 goals in 17 appearances. It is mainly because of him that SVE greets the new year from an outstanding second place in the standings.

But in the middle of the season, Ebnouatlib is now moving up a level. The rising star is expected to address the severe personnel issues in Frankfurt's attacking center.

Due to the absences of Jonathan Burkardt and Michy Batshuayi, as well as Elye Wahi's lack of form, there is a significant gap in SGE's front line. Therefore, another goal scorer is likely to be signed in the coming days, with Arnaud Kalimuendo considered the most promising candidate.

title: How did curling become a Winter Olympics sensation? Inside the sports' unique history
description: More than 2.3 million people ‚Äî or one of every 18 Canadians ‚Äî participate in the sport of curling. A look at how the quirky sport became an Olympic star.
fullText:
Jason Hills grew up in a rural hamlet in southern Alberta so small there were no traffic lights. Which wasn‚Äôt a problem because there wasn‚Äôt any traffic either.

‚ÄúThere was nothing else really to do,‚Äù Hills said. ‚ÄúSo if you weren‚Äôt curling you‚Äôd go hang out at the curling rink. It‚Äôs a community thing. It‚Äôs like everyone gets together.‚Äù

In much of the world curling is a curiosity, a sport which, like luge or the biathlon, surfaces every four years at the Winter Olympics ‚Äî¬†as it will do in February¬†in¬†Cortina D‚ÄôAmpezzo,¬†Italy¬†‚Äî then quickly fades from view.

In Canada, however, it‚Äôs as much a part of the culture as poutine and maple syrup.

More than 2.3 million people ‚Äî or one of every 18 Canadians ‚Äî participate in the sport annually. That‚Äôs about 100 times the level of participation in the U.S. And more than 11 million Canadians watched the sport on TV in 2024, according to estimates from Curling Canada, the national governing body for the sport.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just embedded in the fabric of Canada,‚Äù said Elaine Dagg-Jackson, an Olympic bronze medalist and now one of Canada‚Äôs top curling coaches. ‚ÄúCanadians have a real identity with what curling is and what it stands for. It‚Äôs a gracious sport where people are being polite. They shake hands before and after the game.

‚ÄúThe curling rink was just a really good place to be in Canada. And still is. It just really suits the culture.‚Äù

The objectives of the sport are simple: Teams of two to four players slide 44-pound granite stones, also known as rocks, down a narrow 150-foot-long sheet of ice toward a target area called the house, aiming to get their stone closest to the center of the house. One or two players from the throwing team use carbon-fiber brooms to sweep the ice in front of the moving stone, influencing its path and speed.

A round of play ends when each team has thrown eight stones; in Olympic curling, a match consists of 10 ends, eight in mixed curling, with games typically lasting two to three hours.

The simplicity of the sport is both its charm and its curse. Because there is no running, jumping or lifting of heavy objects, everyone from young children to octogenarians can, and do, compete in amateur curling in Canada.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs relatively inexpensive and it‚Äôs relatively accessible,‚Äù said Heather Mair, an associate professor at the University of Waterloo. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not a hard sport to play and have fun at. It‚Äôs hugely entertaining. And you can really play your whole life.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know too many sports you could go out with your grandfather and participate. It can be really family-oriented as a sport.‚Äù

But while it looks easy, to excel at the highest levels, where millimeters separate winners from losers in competitions that can stretch for as long as seven hours over multiple days, the sport requires surprising strength, stamina, precision and agility.

‚ÄúIt definitely takes a toll on your body,‚Äù Rachel Homan, a three-time Canadian Olympian and three-time world champion, said during a break in training on a bright Edmonton morning. ‚ÄúThat part of the game is maybe overlooked; the physical toll it takes. It‚Äôs definitely demanding.‚Äù

The curling events at¬†February's Winter Olympics will be held at the Cortina Olympic Stadium in Cortina D‚ÄôAmpezzo, one of four event clusters in and around Milan. Canada, which has medaled in curling in every Olympics in the modern era, winning a record six golds, will send a dozen athletes ‚Äî including Homan, the reigning world champion ‚Äî to Italy to compete in the men‚Äôs, women‚Äôs and mixed doubles.

The U.S., which has won two Olympic curling medals, both in the men‚Äôs competition, will also have a dozen curlers in Italy competing in all three events. But if the sport is a national pastime in Canada, one that competes with hockey for fans and media attention, it remains something of an oddity in the U.S., where it draws huge TV audiences every four years during the Olympics, then fades from view until the next Winter Games.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs so frustrating to see curling become the next best thing to sliced bread for a month and then it comes off the radar for four years,‚Äù said Korey Dropkin, a five-time U.S. champion and a 2023 world champion in mixed doubles. ‚ÄúI want to see something that‚Äôs on national television in the U.S. every week. I want to be able to expose our amazing sport to the U.S. audience day in, day out.

‚ÄúI hope that in the near future we‚Äôll be able to create more opportunities for exposure for curling.‚Äù

Curling was born in Scotland in the early 16th¬†century but grew up centuries later on the Canadian prairies, where the severe weather, rural landscape and boredom provided fertile ground.

‚ÄúIn many parts of the country there‚Äôs long, long winters,‚Äù Dagg-Jackson said. ‚ÄúThe farmers would be busy all summer, but in the winter they were looking for something to do. So the old adage in Canada is you could go to any town in rural Canada and find a grain elevator and a curling rink.‚Äù

The sport, which predates hockey by several decades, was brought to Montreal by Scottish emigrants during the colonial period, more than a half-century before Canada became a country. It then moved west as settlers pushed into what would become the central provinces, where the game was played on ponds and lakes before coming indoors.

In many ways the sport and the harsh conditions in which it thrived embodied the traditional values and traits ‚Äî resilience, community, politeness, resourcefulness ‚Äî that have come to define Canada‚Äôs unique ‚Äúnorthern character.‚Äù

Mair, the Waterloo professor, has studied the role curling played in creating social and inter-generational connections and found the sport may have been more important from a mental perspective than from a physical one.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know if you can appreciate what a Canadian winter is like, but anything that gets us out of our homes and talking to one another is really, really important,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúWe know how necessary it is that we spend time socializing with one another, especially in the dark winter days.‚Äù

As a result, it quickly became hugely popular, but for reasons that went beyond sport. Most curling rinks, Mair said, provide social spaces where players can visit with the people they‚Äôre competing against.

‚ÄúSo you‚Äôre sitting there for half an hour with people that you might never run into in any other part of your life and you start to build social relationships,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIn really small rural communities, those are pretty essential. That‚Äôs kind of how it started.‚Äù

It‚Äôs also why the flat lands of Saskatchewan, Manitoba and Alberta became the earliest hotbeds of curling, which aligned well with the farming season. But the sport didn‚Äôt stay there. Curling clubs soon sprung up on Army bases and in fishing communities, in big cities and small towns, where it was taught in schools and played in retirement homes. (Curling has taken a different path in the U.S., where it has become popular in nontraditional winter-sports areas such as North Carolina, Florida, Texas and the San Francisco Bay area.)

‚ÄúThere were entire generations, for the most part, who really had a sense of the game,‚Äù Mair said. ‚ÄúThe[re] were plumbers and carpenters and teachers, they had regular day jobs and yet they were these really talented athletes who would take the sport to these elite levels.

‚ÄúSo you could come from a teeny, tiny club and you might know someone who‚Äôs playing in the national championship.‚Äù

That romanticism inspired a radio play and novella by W.O. Mitchell, a writer and broadcaster who chronicled life on the Canadian prairies in the mid 20th¬†century. In ‚ÄúThe Black Bonspiel of Willie MacCrimmon,‚Äù which was also adapted for television, a cobbler from a small town in rural Alberta strikes a deal with the devil to trade his soul for curling success.

But as curling moved from the prairies to the cities, the object lessons the sport taught changed as well. If Mitchell‚Äôs tale is a decades-old take on the timeless tug of war between good and evil, ‚ÄúThe New Canadian Curling Club,‚Äù a 2018 comedy by playwright Mark Crawford in which four immigrants show up for a learn-to-curl class, is a modern exploration of multiculturalism and acceptance.

What the immigrants share, however, is a belief that understanding Canada starts with understanding curling.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs weird and wonderful. And like all good things, it takes a little time to appreciate,‚Äù Mair, who teaches in the department of recreation and leisure studies at Waterloo, said of the sport. ‚ÄúAt first glance you‚Äôre not totally sure what‚Äôs going on. And then as the layers start to kind of unfold, you realize just how interesting and complicated and engaging it can be.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fun. It really is. It‚Äôs quirky and fun. And I think we need more of that.‚Äù

But, she added, much of that has changed since curling entered the Olympics.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre at a bit of a crossroads,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúElite sport is doing just fine in a lot of ways. [But] we need to have a different conversation about community sport. It‚Äôs not about a pathway to Olympic gold. It‚Äôs about rebuilding our communities and providing safe and accessible sports for everything. And curling is just so special in that way.‚Äù

Curling debuted in the Winter Games in 1924 with just three countries taking part; Great Britain, which fielded a team of Scottish curlers, won the gold medal. But the sport didn‚Äôt return to the official Olympic program for another 74 years and when it did, the exposure fueled interest in winter sports powerhouses such as China, Japan and South Korea, but also in Afghanistan, Andorra, Bolivia, the Virgin Islands, Kuwait and Mexico, which are all among the 67 members of the World Curling Assn.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a little bit of perception from America that curling is small potatoes. And it probably is compared to the big four sports,‚Äù said Marc Kennedy, a world and Olympic champion from Canada who will be competing in his fourth Olympics in Italy. ‚ÄúBut it‚Äôs a big deal. Arguably one of the fastest-growing sports internationally. It‚Äôs massive in Asia. Some of our most popular athletes are from Japan.‚Äù

That added competitiveness ‚Äî 30 countries attempted to qualify for this year‚Äôs Olympic tournament ‚Äî has not only raised the stakes and professionalized the sport, it also threatens to crush curling‚Äôs gracious and polite traditions in a stampede for the top of the medal podium. In last spring‚Äôs world championship in Canada, for example, Chinese athletes were accused of touching a stone with a broom, kicking a stone and illegal sweeping ‚Äî all forbidden acts.

In most other sports, that would have been considered gamesmanship. In curling, the accusations alone were an affront to the sport‚Äôs tradition and dignity.

‚ÄúIn curling you always divulge that you broke a rule ‚Ä¶ and apologize,‚Äù said Dagg-Jackson, the former Olympian turned coach.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs supposed to be a gentleman‚Äôs game. You‚Äôre supposed to call your own fouls,‚Äù added Chris Plys, a three-time U.S. Olympian. ‚ÄúNow we‚Äôre starting to see people doing questionable things.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs sad because the best part of the game is just how honest everything is. And there‚Äôs people out there [now] that are willing to do whatever it takes to win.‚Äù

Those athletes certainly aren‚Äôt cheating for the money since curlers, even at the highest level, have often had to work regular jobs to pay the bills. That could change this spring with the launch of the Rock League, the sport‚Äôs first professional competition, which will begin play shortly after the Milan-Cortina Olympics.

‚ÄúThe Rock League is going to be a huge new chapter to the sport,‚Äù said Dropkin, the Olympian who will captain the U.S. Rock League team. ‚ÄúThat is going to present a whole lot of opportunities to curlers. Curlers now, curlers [in] the pipeline. They can actually make a living.‚Äù

The five-week circuit will feature six teams of five men and five women ‚Äî one from the Asian-Pacific, two from Canada, two from Europe and one representing the U.S. ‚Äî playing a variety of formats during stops in the U.S. and Canada. Competitors will not just earn money based on performance, but will receive salaries as well.

Historically the sport has relied heavily on prize money, which doesn‚Äôt go far. Kennedy‚Äôs winning five-man team at the 2025 Brier, the annual Canadian men‚Äôs championships, split $108,000 of the tournament‚Äôs $300,000 purse last March, which didn‚Äôt leave much after paying for travel and housing at the 10-day event.

The Dodgers will pay Shohei Ohtani more than that every time he comes to the plate over the next 10 seasons.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think any of us get into curling with the idea of making millions of dollars,‚Äù said Kennedy, 43, a father of two who sold his frozen-food franchise 14 years ago to support his curling career. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve got a lot of curlers out there that still play for the love of the game and for the opportunity to represent Canada at the Olympics or World Championships.

‚ÄúIf money was your motivation, then you‚Äôre probably in the wrong sport.‚Äù

For Homan, 36, a mother of three young children who has traditionally relied on sponsorships, stipends from the national federation and winnings from underfunded tours such as the Grand Slam of Curling to make ends meet, the Rock League has the potential to change not only her life, but her legacy as well.

‚ÄúIn this league, being a part of it, might not mean anything for me financially right now. But it‚Äôs more about what you‚Äôre leaving behind and what you‚Äôre helping create,‚Äù said Homan, who will captain one of the league‚Äôs two Canadian teams.

Financing a professional league isn‚Äôt the only challenge curling will face coming out of the Milan-Cortina Games, though. Because while the Olympics may help the sport gather viewers, it has done little to reverse a steady decline in participation at the grassroots level, which is robbing the sport of its future athletes.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just hard to get young kids introduced to it and have access to it,‚Äù Kennedy said. ‚ÄúBack in the ‚Äò50s, ‚Äò60s, ‚Äò70s and ‚Äò80s it was the community center. Everybody kind of learned curling, especially out west. That‚Äôs what was driving a huge part of our sport for a long time.‚Äù

Not any more. Canada, like the U.S., has seen millions of people flee rural areas for big cities over the last several decades and as a result the local curling rink is no longer the civic hub it was when Jason Hills was growing up on the frigid plains of central Alberta. And what investment there is in the sport is now being directed to events such as the Olympics, the Grand Slam of Curling or the fledgling Rock League, not to building more community rinks.

‚ÄúCurling had to pivot a bit,‚Äù said Dagg-Jackson, who takes her five grandchildren curling. ‚ÄúIt used to be all about membership, about the thousands and thousands of curlers across the country. Now those few competitive curlers that shine in the spotlight are known to all Canadians because they‚Äôre on television all the time and they draw attention to the sport.

‚ÄúFifty years ago you just waited at the rink and people showed up because it was the place to be. Big events, Olympics, pro leagues, that‚Äôs the future of curling. But the culture and the lore, the history of curling, it‚Äôll always be there.‚Äù

title: WMBD Prep Sports Recap: Dec. 27, 2025
description: PEORIA, Ill. (WMBD) ‚Äì Quarterfinal Saturday at the State Farm Holiday Class and Central Illinois is well represented across the four respective divisions. Normal Community, Peoria High, and the Fieldcrest boys advanced in the two boys brackets while Washington, Morton, Eureka and U-High won to move forward to the Final Four in the two girls [‚Ä¶]
fullText:
PEORIA, Ill. (WMBD) ‚Äì Quarterfinal Saturday at the State Farm Holiday Class and Central Illinois is well represented across the four respective divisions.

Normal Community, Peoria High, and the Fieldcrest boys advanced in the two boys brackets while Washington, Morton, Eureka and U-High won to move forward to the Final Four in the two girls brackets.

At the Manual shootout, the Rams came back to beat Pekin and Limestone defeated Springfield Lanphier.

At the Princeville Holiday Tournament, Brimfield knocked off host Princeville in the semifinals and Elmwood defeated Midland. The two rivals will square off in the title game on Monday.

In the girls tournament, Midland and Elmwood will face off for the championship after defeated Princeville and Tremont, respectively.

title: Letters to Sports: Playing the blame game in USC-Notre Dame debacle
description: Readers of the Los Angeles Times Sports section share their thoughts on the USC-Notre Dame rivalry, the Rams, UCLA, Angels and college football.
fullText:
Bill Plaschke writes, ‚ÄúIf the Trojans truly want to return to greatness, being selected for the CFP is the goal. Not beating Notre Dame. Not even beating UCLA.‚Äù That's 100% wrong.

As a USC alum (1965) and longtime fan, those are the only things that do matter. I have often said that if USC beats UCLA or Notre Dame, the coach deserves another season. To give up this grand tradition in pursuit of the arguably artificial and profit-driven CFP would be an unforgivable sin.

A USC national football championship without playing Notre Dame rings hollow ‚Äî an asterisked title, a meal that never satisfies, a taste you can‚Äôt quite wash away. It may shine in the record books, but it will always feel unfinished to those who know what real college football tradition demands. Earth to Lincoln Riley: an undefeated season is still a loss without playing the Fighting Irish. What‚Äôs next? If UCLA becomes competitive, then there will be no crosstown game?

So the Fighting Irish own a series edge of 53-37, have won 3 in a row, 7 of the last 8, and 11 of the last 15 games. Yet Bill Plaschke now claims that Notre Dame is running away from the series and is afraid of "Ole SC." To paraphrase the late, great Jim Healy, Plaschke is on the Leonard Tose highway!

Notre Dame is the Burger King of college football ‚Äî always having it their way. From backdoor deals with the corrupt [CFP] guaranteeing a playoff spot if they finish ranked in the top 12 to refusing to join a conference so that they can pocket all bowl game money, the Irish are treated like college football royalty. Glad USC told the Irish toddlers they can‚Äôt have ice cream for breakfast!

‚ÄúUSC and Notre Dame recognize how special our rivalry is to our fans ‚Ä¶" A joint statement by the athletic directors of the two schools. Really? Fake news!

No USC-Notre Dame football game! Who‚Äôs next to be cut from the Notre Dame football schedule, Navy? Oh wait, the Irish can‚Äôt afford to drop Navy. That might hurt their chance$ at a playoff berth.

I don't think firing the Rams' special teams coach is the answer. How about running some tackling drills with the defensive backs during the week. I know there's "no crying in baseball," but is it now "there's no tackling in football?" Throw in some deep coverage drills too!

So it looks like athletic director Martin Jarmond has forced UCLA followers to accept his decisions made outside of public scrutiny once again with a contract extension for Mick Cronin. If you haven‚Äôt noticed, UCLA basketball has been sliding into mediocrity. Seats at home games are increasingly vacant. USC is outrecruiting UCLA. Prices for seats would make you think you are going to see a top-tier team. UCLA has been sitting on distant memories. How long will it take to fully trash those memories? Jarmond‚Äôs easy-way-out decision is dooming the basketball program.

Having been a Kings fan since Luc Robitaille's rookie year, I have seen some very good Kings teams and some very bad ones. But never have I seen a team with so much potential and skill be so absolutely lethargic and unwatchable this season. This team currently ranks 31st out of 32 teams in overall scoring and power-play percentage. How bad is it? As of Christmas Eve, in the last 5 games the team has a total of 8 goals and 8 assists, or 16 points, the sum total of all 18 skaters on the ice over 5 games. Connor McDavid, the leading NHL scorer, has racked up 15 points in his last 5 games ‚Ä¶ just one skater. The saying goes that the fish rots from the head. Time to show coach Jim Hiller and his entire staff the door. A fresh start, a new motivator. Is Darryl Sutter available again?

Ronald J Peters
Colorado Springs, Colo.

In his Dec. 22 analysis, Bill Shaikin implies that payroll is the difference between winning and losing baseball teams. For the Angels, the on-field problems are rooted in off-the-field issues that have gone largely unchecked for at least a decade. As Angel fans, we can only hope that the settling of the Tyler Skaggs lawsuit, a low 2026 payroll, and one-year contracts to the GM and manager indicate that Arte Moreno is readying the Angels for sale. New ownership and upper management are what‚Äôs needed, not a higher payroll.

It was fitting that rapper 50 Cent performed live during Oklahoma‚Äôs first-round College Football Playoff loss, since the Sooners basically showed up for only two quarters.

The Los Angeles Times welcomes expressions of all views. Letters should be brief and become the property of The Times. They may be edited and republished in any format. Each must include a valid mailing address and telephone number. Pseudonyms will not be used.

title: Prep sports recap for Dec. 26, 2025
description: PEORIA, Ill. (WMBD/WYZZ) ‚Äî Brimfield looked like a top-seeded team Friday. Senior Connor Doe returned from an ankle injury to score 27 points and lead Brimfield to a 65-36 win over Galva in the opening round of the 97th Princeville Holiday Tournament. The Indians, the No. 1 seed in the tournament, will play host Princeville [‚Ä¶]
fullText:
PEORIA, Ill. (WMBD/WYZZ) ‚Äî Brimfield looked like a top-seeded team Friday.

Senior Connor Doe returned from an ankle injury to score 27 points and lead Brimfield to a 65-36 win over Galva in the opening round of the 97th Princeville Holiday Tournament. The Indians, the No. 1 seed in the tournament, will play host Princeville in the tourney semifinals Saturday.

Princeville beat Peru St. Bede, 43-34. On the other side of the bracket, Elmwood beat Henry-Senachwine, 52-49, and Midland defeat Peoria Heights, 71-62, to advance to the tournament semifinals.

Area winners in the 64-team State Farm Classic included Peoria High, Normal Community, Dunlap, U-High, Central Catholic, Fieldcrest and U-High. The four-day tournament runs through Dec. 30.

Other boys basketball winners in holiday tournament play included Metamora, Lexington, Tremont and Deer Creek-Mackinaw.

In girls basketball, Dani Guedet scored 28 points to lead defending champion Washington to a 79-29, over Bloomington in the opening round of the State Farm Classic. Morton beat Normal Community in the large-school girls bracket, as well.

Other girls winners at the State Farm Classic included Eureka, El Paso-Gridley, Central Catholic, U-High. Girls winners at the Lee Westerman Princeville Holiday Tournament included Tremont, Elmwood, Midland and Princeville.

At the Manual Girls Shootout, Limestone, East Peoria and Pekin split two games apiece. Peoria High and Manual lost both their games.

title: A champion ping pong player who avoided sports most of her life says it's never too late to start something new
description: Carol Klenfner avoided sports most of her life after a car crash dislocated her hip. She picked up ping pong at 69 and has been thriving ever since.
fullText:
Carol Klenfner had played ping pong on and off since growing up and into adulthood, but it wasn't until she was 69 that she picked up the paddle to compete.

Within just a few months of playing consistently, she began to notice a difference.

"I remember when I started playing ping pong," she told Business Insider's Sarah Andersen in April, "I noticed that my reflexes were faster than they had been."

Now, after more than a decade of playing and competing at the national level and earning more than 50 medals, she attributes the sport to keeping her mind sharp and engaged as she enters her 80s.

Andersen followed Klenfner as she trained for the 2025 National Senior Games in Des Moines this summer:

Ping pong's speed demands full attention ‚Äî the spin of the ball, the bounce off the paddle, and the angle of each return. That focus, repeated hundreds of times a day, has helped tune both Klenfner's body and mind, she said.

"If I'm in the bathroom and something falls off the medicine chest, my hand is there catching it before it even registers in my head," Klenfner said.

Klenfner's experience aligns with what researchers have found on the effect of regular physical activity and strength training on the aging human brain.

Building balance, coordination, and fine motor control can strengthen neural connections, reducing the risk of cognitive decline and frailty in older adults.

What's more, picking up ping pong later in life gave Klenfner a renewed sense of adventure.

"The single most important thing that I've learned, and the advice that I would give to somebody who wants to pick up something new later in life, is that it's never too late to learn," she said. "It's never too late to start something new."

Before tackling table tennis, Klenfner had spent most of her life avoiding sports. She was injured in a car crash in college that dislocated her hip. After that, running, playing tennis, and general athletics were off the table.

"It changed the trajectory of my life till now," she said of the event. "I kind of stopped playing sports at that point."

Then, in her late 60s, she saw the documentary "Ping Pong" on PBS, which follows a group of seniors, ages 80 to 100, going to the World Masters Championship.

"I watched that documentary and I said, 'Well, I can't play tennis anymore because of my back and my sciatica, but I think I could play ping pong,'" she said.

Now, at 80, she plays table tennis and trains several times a week.

She's competed in many events, including the Empire State Senior Games and the National Senior Games. She won gold for women's singles at the national games in Pittsburgh in 2023 and took fifth at the 2025 games in Iowa, which disappointed her but didn't deter her from continuing.

"Winning's better, but I love to play and playing is the goal," she said.

Klenfner says she works out every day, morning and night. Space is limited in her small studio Manhattan apartment, but she gets creative.

She completes about 60 squats, including one-legged squats, each morning while her oatmeal warms.

Then, she'll do some stretches specifically for her back and sciatica, followed by side planks to strengthen her oblique muscles, which are key for the side-to-side motion in ping pong, she says.

After that, she'll typically head to either PingPod to practice with their coaches or her private Pilates trainer, whom she sees twice a week.

In the evenings, she completes sets of resistance exercises with a weight band that she attaches to the only door in her place: the bathroom door.

Klenfner says there are three main reasons she's so committed to exercising daily: staying strong for her tournaments, staying strong for her life, and helping her mental health. "I am happy when I'm moving," she said.

"I'm currently living the best chapter of my life in a lot of ways. I am doing what I want to do when I want to do it."

title: 'Like hitting a lotto ticket.' Why sports memorabilia collectors pursue chase cards
description: The trading card business is so big, the ecosystem has created specialized markets within it. Collectors can chase a specific team, or stick to vintage cards, among other options.
fullText:
Trading sports cards is a game of negotiation for Greg Petikyan. Within seconds, he talked to multiple vendors at Frank and Son Collectible Show last month offering the same card: a 2025 Panini Donruss Saquon Barkley Downtown.

The first deal consisted of a 3-for-1 exchange, with an additional couple of hundred dollars to sweeten the deal or a straight purchase for $460. As the vendor looked through his phone for the value of the cards he asked for, Petikyan told him he‚Äôll circle back.

Instead, the entrepreneur offered it to Eric Mitchel, another booth owner, across the aisle and sold it. A rectangular cardboard collectible with the Super Bowl-winning running back in front of the Philadelphia skyline sold for $300.

‚ÄúToo late,‚Äù Petikyan said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll still buy those cards I asked for.‚Äù

Nothing personal, just business.

Trading and collecting cards, an industry valued at $14.9 billion in 2024, is estimated to reach $52.1 billion within the next decade, according to Market Decipher report. The sports memorabilia business, as a whole, is estimated to reach a value of $271.2 billion by 2034.

E-commerce platforms like Fanatics Live and Whatnot have turned business transactions involving the cards of sports legends into entertainment and helped grow the market. Heritage Auctions sold the most expensive card in August. The collectible known as the "holy grail" by basketball collectors was a 2007-08 Upper Deck Exquisite Collection Dual Logoman Autographs Michael Jordan and Kobe Bryant card.

The one-of-one sold for $12.932 million, a sum that topped a Mickey Mantle card that went for $12.6 million in August 2022. The Jordan-Bryant card is the second-most expensive sports collectible of all time, trailing Babe Ruth's 1932 World Series Jersey, which he wore when he called his shot, that cost $24.12 million.

Last Friday, Heritage Auctions set a sales record for the year by crossing the $2 billion mark. The cards sold that day included a 2003 Upper Deck Exquisite Collection Dual Logoman Jordan-Bryant card for $3,172,000 ‚Äî this one was not autographed.

The trading card business has grown so much, the ecosystem has created specialized markets within it. Collectors can chase a specific team; stick to vintage cards; complete a set of prints with mistakes; chase specific relics of their favorite team; or even just buy cards to resell them for the sole purpose of buying more to flip.

"I know for a fact, a lot of men like to show off their collection," Adam Campbell, sports cards specialist with Heritage Auction, said. "People love to have good, cool collections," he added.

The type of chase can change the direction of a business transaction, said George Pe√±a, 53, another booth owner at Frank and Son, an old Sam's Club that now houses more than 200 vendors selling and showcasing collectible merchandise three days a week.

Kids go into his booth and negotiate with him. Most of the time he doesn‚Äôt necessarily need a card from them but engages with them to give them the experience.

‚ÄúFamily members get all excited for them,‚Äù Pe√±a said.

But when dealing with people like Petikyan, the stakes change.

‚ÄúNegotiations are a little different with those kinds of people because they want to make money and we want to make money,‚Äù he said as he quipped with Petikyan.

Some collectors have turned into investors because the value of cards is so volatile. It changes in real time ‚Äî it's fast, unpredictable and relentless. The moment Dodgers designated hitter and pitcher Shohei Ohtani hit three home runs and struck out 10 batters in Game 4 of the 2025 NLCS, the value of his cards went up. But it cuts both ways ‚Äî the moment Cleveland Guardians pitcher Emmanuel Clase was indicted on federal charges for wire fraud conspiracy and bribery, the value of his cards dipped.

‚ÄúThe value of cards is not based on anything else, whatsoever, except for hype and buzz‚Äù Campbell said. ‚Äú[It's] entirely arbitrary.‚Äù

Collecting trading cards has been a part of the culture since Goodwin Tobacco Company released the first set of individual players‚Äô baseball cards in 1886. The N167 Old Judge sets were inserted into tiny cigarette boxes to increase sales and to make sure the cards were not damaged in transit.

Since the tobacco industry started the trade, sports cards have endured changes through generations, each defined by specific characteristics.

The vintage era, before the 1980s, ushered in simpler designs, lower print runs and sets featuring the legends of all the sports. Then came the junk wax period, marked by mass overproduction that devalued the product. The current ultra modern era evolved the market into investments, scarcity, and digitized the business with websites like Arena Club, which repackages pre-graded cards as slab packs.

No matter the changes, there remains a common thread within collectors throughout the years: opening packages and feeling a bump of euphoria when a chase card, a sought-after item, appears.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the best feeling ever, imagine getting a $1,000 card for like 20, 30 bucks?‚Äù Petikyan said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like hitting a lotto ticket, but better, because it could go up in value depending on the player.‚Äù

Petikyan, 27 from Montebello, runs a page called Strictly Pullz on the shopping app Whatnot where he opens boxes and auctions the items within them. Any card pulled from a team that's purchased by the individual will be shipped to them. On occasion, he inserts a card with higher value to hype a specific set.

To some, the business is intertwined with collecting.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll use some of the money that I am able to make on the business side, to add to my personal collection,‚Äù Mitchel said. ‚ÄúFinding items for the personal collection, I wouldn‚Äôt find if I wasn‚Äôt out for the business part of it.‚Äù

Regardless of motivation, pulling a card worth more than the price paid for will remain priceless.

‚ÄúI just bought a pack and I pulled a card worth $1,000,‚Äù Campbell said, speaking as a collector. ‚ÄúIt can change your whole day, and maybe your whole week, maybe a whole month or even a whole year every time you open a pack.‚Äù

But, collecting cards is more than just the value of each, Campbell said.

‚ÄúDo this because you like sports, do this because you love collecting.‚Äù

title: Top 10 Lowcountry sports stories of 2025
description: MT. PLEASANT, S.C. (WCBD) ‚Äì A lot to celebrate this holiday season as it was another great year for Lowcountry sports. It was tough to dwindle down the top ten stories of 2025 but we did our best.
fullText:
MT. PLEASANT, S.C. (WCBD) ‚Äì A lot to celebrate this holiday season as it was another great year for Lowcountry sports. It was tough to dwindle down the top ten stories of 2025 but we did our best.

Top story #10 ‚Äì 2025 was a banner year for Mt. Pleasants Debbie Antonelli, literally. In January the NC State alum was inducted into the Wolfpack basketball Ring of Honor for her contributions to the sport. On Halloween the town of Mt. Pleasant officially named the gym at town hall in her honor. ‚ÄúThe Deb is a testament to Antonelli‚Äôs work promoting the game and the Special Olympics as she hopes to serve as an inspiration for other young girls like herself with a love of basketball.

Top story #9 ‚Äì Berkeley High School has been around since 1912, in its entire school history the Stags had yet to win a state title in basketball. That all changed one March afternoon in Florence when the Lady Stags defeated Greenwood for the SCHSL 5A D2 championship. Berkeley alum head coach Crystal Peace overwhelmed as her Stags finally reached the mountain top.

Top story #8 ‚Äì In James Island¬†baseball‚Äôs last game in 4A in 2024, they won their third state title in school history. Fast forward to the last day of May as the Trojans were down to their last three outs in extra innings in the decisive game for the 5A D1 crown against Lexington. Collin Anderson drove in the tying run with a ringing double to right center. Later in the bottom of the eighth with Anderson on second, Jake Amman comes through with the biggest knock of his life driving in Anderson as the Trojans go back to back defeating the Wildcats in dramatic fashion. Can I get an Amman?

Top story #7 ‚Äì John McKissick holds the record for the most wins as a high school head football coach in the state, and probably will never be passed. Coach has company in flower town as Pinewood Prep head basketball coach Pat Eidson became the states all time winningest head coach in January. With a 67 ‚Äì 31 win over Palmetto Christian, pat won his 944th game as a head coach. After stops at Easley Christian and Northside Christian, Eidson has been at Pinewood since 1990.

Top story #6 ‚Äì Coastal Carolina baseball was two wins away from their second national title in school history. After winning the Sun Belt regular season and tournament titles, the Chants breezed through the Conway regional before sweeping Auburn down on the plains in the Auburn super regional. Coastal‚Äôs win streak reached a remarkable 26 games in a row when they defeated Louisville to advance to the CWS finals falling in two games to the national champion LSU Tigers. Chanticleer alum, head coach Kevin Schnall guided CCU to the most wins in school history with 56 in 2025.

Top story #5 ‚Äì After coming oh so close to winning his first title on the PGA Tour, Academic Magnet alum Andrew Novak would fall in a playoff at the Heritage to Justin Thomas. Andrew would rebound the following week winning the Zurich Classic with playing partner Ben Griffin for his first title on tour. Novak capped off 2025 by winning another team event, the Grant Thornton Invitational with l-p-g-a‚Äôs Lauren Coughlin.

Top story #4 ‚Äì Dr. Quinn gave Nicols college the medicine in October as Stratford alum Montie Quinn set a new NCAA single game rushing record across all divisions as he ran for an absurd 522 yards on just 20 carries in Currie College‚Äôs 71 ‚Äì 27 victory. Montie added seven touchdowns, his longest coming from 85 yards and finished the season with 2446 rushing yards. Once again leading the NCAA across all divisions.

Top story #3 ‚Äì SC State won the MEAC title for a second year in a row under Chennis Berry. The Bulldogs would play in the Celebration Bowl for a second year in a row as well. After falling by 21 in 2024, they trailed by 21 at the half against Prairie View A&M. SCSU responded in the third quarter tying things at 21 and would go on to force overtime. In the fourth OT, SC State scored the first two point try then stopped the Panthers attempt as pandemonium reigned and confetti fell as the Bulldogs claimed the HBCU national title for the first time since 2021.

Top story #2 ‚Äì While the Bulldogs won a title in the ATL, OCA won a third straight title in Orangeburg on State‚Äôs home turf. Oceanside punished BHP for a second year in a row winning back to back 3A state titles, the third overall title in a row as Brent LaPrad became the third different head coach to win a championship with the Landsharks. OCA became the first Lowcountry program to three-peat since Summerville from 1982-1984.

Top story #1 ‚Äì After winning gold in the 4√ó100 relay at the Paris Olympics in 2024, Georgetown‚Äôs Melissa Jefferson-Wooden became the fastest woman in the world as she set a new world record in the 100 meters at the World Athletics Championship in Tokyo with a blazing time of 10.61 seconds. Jefferson-Wooden would go on to win the 200 meters at the championship as well.
